review_title: Great people, fast pace environment, decent benefits
job_title: Clinical Lab Scientist in San Francisco, CA
pros: - Great people to work with. All genuinely helpful. No competition because evaluations /raises are not by performance. Friendly environment. Makes work tolerable. Real team work. - Management /leadership is awesome in my department. - Stable position - Work hours (for dayshift) are great. Overtime is available if you want. - Work-life balance (despite the over time, but you earn extra comp hours from there and use for your vacation). Every department has their own vacation policies/flexibilities. - Hourly rate is higher than most. - Work is repetitive, but patient cases make it interesting. - Work is directly connected with patient care, thus rewarding experience you see first hand. - More contact and communication with clinical staff - RNs, Coordinators, Residents and attendings. - Unionized position = job protection and contract negotiations. - Get a pension after vested for 5 years.
cons: - Short-staffed. Busier workflow. Increased overtime needed. - High turnover because people live farther and want to work closer to home. - Growth in the field depends on how young the leadership staff is. Generally slower. - No steps to distinguish experience amongst bench CLSs. - Technical growth/knowledge can be stagnant, especially when in the same department, and unless you are a higher CLS doing more projects. - Face pace environment can be very stressful. - Less money to take home: contributions are to the Union dues and to pension (but must stay at least 5 years to get it) and health insurance.

job_title: Director in San Francisco, CA
pros: A great place to work if you are older and want a pension. If you are 50+ and looking at this as an option, there will be money left for you (now 40 years for full, so 10 years is 25% a year, at the end of your career, for the rest of your life). Some great employees and lovely people, reasonable benefits.
cons: Where to begin: 1. 25% of the staff are dead weight. Literally RIP (retired in place), or so heavily protected by the union or multiple categories of protected status (age, race, gender etc.) that they cannot be touched. You will carry your lazy coworker, if that isn't for you, this employer isn't for you. 2. There is a huge focus on talking about or launching initiatives about DEI, but zero actual action on doing anything effective. 3. Faculty are abusive (not all, but enough), and there is nothing that will be done about it. 4. Pay... pay is low for the area, pay is kept low by "equity" so you can't make more than someone with more experience, and paychecks are late or wrong OFTEN... the new statewide system (UC PATH) doesn't work, and the result is late or wrong pay, incorrect deductions, and tax issues frequently. 5. Leadership is totally uninspiring. A generation of horrible oppressive Boomer leaders (mostly women), finally retired, but the Gen X leaders below them are insipid, zero strategy, and just want to hold on to retirement. 6. Systems don't work, and no one fixes them and don't care. 7. Training is, at best, patchy

job_title: IT Help Desk Technician I in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Clarity on available overtime, job opportunities, upcoming raises
Structured work hours / same schedule every week
full time work from home / remote
Knowledge Base with hundreds of peer-written and reviewed articles
Opportunity to learn new skills 
Monthly 1on1s with management to provide feedback / ask questions
Clear and reasonable targets for performance expectations
Variety of programs, applications and types of problems keep you from dealing with the same issue all day
Work with students, faculty, doctors, nurses, admin, etc for a wide variety of learning experiences and people
Incredibly nice, helpful, and responsive team
WELL STAFFED, and not afraid to hire more people to make sure the team is large enough to meet demand
cons:
Pay is fairly structured, so if you are an exceptional performer you likely will receive raises at a similar rate to other people meeting/exceeding expectations (but will have promotion opportunities)
Training is structured for first week, after which you are expected to ask questions if you don't know anything
Large learning curve at first to learn all the niche programs, to be able to support hundreds of different departments and types of users

job_title: Data Systems Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Aside from a few exceptions, everyone here wants you to succeed and they push you to grow. You are encouraged to learn more, network, and are given opportunities to show off your work and build your reputation. You will build a strong repertoire here.
If full time, you will get all the health benefits you're looking for and more.
cons:
The pay is below industry, but they are working on matching it. Expect at least a 3% raise every year.
There are a lot of politics here. You won't have to backstab people to move up, but expect to maneuver through a lot of political minefields and watch your language carefully to appease stakeholders and funders.

job_title: Junior Specialist II in San Francisco, CA
pros: You are surrounded by smart people.
cons:
- Below market salary. No yearly performance bonuses or salary increases. Manager didn't even try to match inflation.
- Constant added responsibility with no wage increase along with it. Normalized expectation to stay longer or to come in during the weekend for the purpose of scientific advancement despite not given overtime pay.
- Research community is extremely toxic and is revolved around the publish or perish mentality. Because of this, many people leave to industry for a better work life balance. There are even instances of PI's causing their HR admin to quit due to added stress.
- Significant amount of mental stress and constant belittlement (I was called a gopher).
- Turnover rate is insane almost as bad as any FAANG company, if not worst.
- Received final paycheck late and it didn't even include vacation pay which was sent a week later.
- No company provided lunches or dinner despite being California's biggest employer.
- Empty promises about perks such as retreats, gym membership, and lunches with no follow through.

TLDR. Only come here if you are passionate about research and don't care about yourself.

job_title: Junior Specialist II in San Francisco, CA
pros:
I really enjoyed my lab and collaborating with other researchers around me. I worked in the Mission Bay campus and I like how it's clean and easily accessible to public transportation (e.g., Muni and the UCSF shuttle to BART). The environment was not too stressful for me as my PI was a vary understanding in kind person. My experience was largely dictated by who the lab members were at the time and how I got along with them. 

I also liked how there's a decent choice of food places around the area like Sparks and other newer restaurants like the one in the Chase Center plaza. 

I was originally hired as an undergraduate intern, then after graduating, I was promoted to Junior Specialist I, then II after a year. I felt like this opportunity boosted my CV because I was able to publish several manuscripts and really taught me all I need to know about benchwork research!

I had good health benefits, including dental, and eye insurance options that I used regularly. Lots of vacation time and because of the COVID pandemic, I racked up a lot of it.
cons: The pay for me was not competitive enough to allow me to live in SF on my own as the cost of living in the city is very high – especially around the Mission Bay area where the apartments are pretty luxurious and new. Hence, I had to commute from the East Bay via the ferry to downtown SF.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros:
This job was at least meaningful. Knowing that my work actually benefited somebody at the end of the day -- patients, research, hospitals, etc.

Chancellor Sam Hawgood and his wife were a pleasure to work with!
cons:
There isn't much room for growth because everyone's waiting for their pension plan. So, half the time, your counterparts are cranky, lazy, and annoyed at you because they're stuck in their ways and know that they can't get fired.

In my department, sh*# rolled down. Like, allllll the way. I often wondered who out of management was finally going to be an advocate for all the worker bees, but I never saw it during my time here. 

My team specifically had a lot of favoritism going on, along with promotions to prove it! Once I saw how they kept passing up some of the best contributors on promotions, but was able to promote the favorites (some even multiple times), I knew it was time to go.

Lastly, having a pension is cool but compensation is not equivalent to the cost of living in San Francisco. Wasn't even close.

review_title: Depending on your goals this could be a great place to work or a terrible place.
job_title: Staff Research Associate II in San Francisco, CA
pros:
The best thing about UCSF is how fascinating the research being done here is. I work everyday and I am impressed by all the things that I do and all the things that are going on around me. The people around me are very interesting people with vibrant personalities that are from all over the world. 

Additionally the employment is very stable. In most positions, after 5 years, you can become "vested" and you are pretty much guaranteed a job for life. I have not experience furloughs or cuts in benefits despite the rough economic times.
cons:
The worst part about UCSF is that high pressure situations often occur due to problematic bosses. Often time PI's push their employees to do more work than can be done within a reasonable work day and people are often forced to stay more than 16 hours without being paid more (even though they are supposed to be).

Additionally the unions seem to be working against the employees in the following three ways: (1) there is no incentive to perform exceptionally (doing the bare minimum is insisted and enforced), (2) there is a minimal and slow upward mobility that encourages very few to stay, and (3) to seniority is valued more than ability.

job_title: Program Coordinator in San Francisco, CA
pros: UCSF positions are well paid compared to similar jobs on other UC campuses. The benefits are quite good. As the largest employer in San Francisco after the city itself it has lots of opportunities for lateral and career moves. There are a lot of wonderful people working there.
cons: UCSF wants to act towards its employees like a poor public university sometimes and a hard-nosed corporation at others, whichever best suits it. They have no qualms about asking employees to donate to UCSF, but they excuse by saying they are a public university the fact that they don't offer employee gift matching, time off for community service, etc.  They cut back on staff and only gave 1 pay increase in 5 years, from 2008-2013, to non-represented staff, during a time of massive increases in the cost of living in San Francisco. Managers are frequently doctors or researchers who are terrible managers and there is no real system to correct the problems that produces.

review_title: UCSF is a very intellectually stimulating environment
job_title: Scientist in San Francisco, CA
pros: Intellectual abilities of people - these are some of the smartest people you will ever work with.  Having these coworkers around results in a very entrepreneurial atmosphere that also brings about a lot of energy and enthusiasm to the workplace. Compared to similar institutions, the amount of collaboration is also much higher at UCSF.  People are always willing to talk or lend a hand or just suggest other sources of information when they don't know the answer.  The facilities are also great.  Every piece of equipment is basically here and since it's a very collegial atmosphere, everything is available for use after asking.
cons: The worse thing is really the hours.  Being a scientist, you have to work anywhere from 50-80 hour weeks to get your experiments done.  Often, that includes a lot of downtime that allows you to catch up on reading articles or running personal errands, but still, when you are spending 10-15 hour days in lab, that can have a huge effect on your morale.  The other major downside is the salary compensation.  Being a public institution, we barely get paid for our time and efforts.  Given the number of hours actually worked, this number works out to something like $3 per hour.

review_title: Great Research, Not So Great Working Environment
job_title: Sra III in San Francisco, CA
pros: There is super exciting research going on everywhere you looks and a really open relationship with industry. Most labs are very well funded so you typically have the freedom to do experiments easily and quickly without having to scrape together the money. They also make sure researchers have access to all the latest equipment in places like the CAT lab.
cons: Incredibly convoluted bureaucracy, much worse than government agencies where I have worked. To get help with anything, from IT, to information about your benefits, to having a lightbulb replaced, you need to submit an online help ticket, it is very very hard to identify an actual point of contact for any department. And then often, before anyone will help you, they will ask for a billing account number. HR representatives are particularly absentee and unhelpful. Everything is meant to be done online but the system is so fragmented and redundant it is impossible to navigate. The result is that a lot of scientists spend a a large portion of their time just trying to keep the lights on or get a formed filled out. There is also no oversight of PIs so if you are joining a lab, do your research very thoroughly on the PI's reputation, if they are abusive or negligent you will very likely be stuck.

job_title: Analyst II in San Francisco, CA
pros: Healthcare benefits are very good. And in general, most UCSF offices are closed for the intersession break, and this is a very nice benefit.
cons: Unfortunately, there is a strong "political" atmosphere that permeates many of the departments there.    And depending on the particular department, there can be very oppressive work environments where excellence is not always encouraged. In my former department, when an individual worker offered a solution to a difficult problem, or a systemic improvement, the management would take it and offer it as their own, never giving credit where credit is due. Also in the particular department where I worked, cordiality and respect was not the norm. In fact, it was discouraged. This may have been especially problematic in the department where I worked, but I am told that there are similar problems at large, across departmental lines.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in San Francisco, CA
pros:
UCSF has a great research environment and a very good infrastructure. This makes it easy to do research, form collaborations for scientific progress. Several eminent scientists, even Nobel laureates, work at UCSF and there are opportunities to interact with them, learn about their research, advice etc. UCSF has a very good interface with industry which gives postdocs a chance to hear about working in the industry. The office of career development at UCSF is available to postdocs to develop their career path. 
The lab environment is genial and give  freedom to work at own pace.
cons: Living in San Francisco is expensive. Compensation for postdocs compared to the work they put in is negligible. Work contracts for postdocs are only for 1 year which makes it difficult to plan ahead. Especially for international postdocs, many problems arise with having just a 1 year visa.

- It's a hub institution in a hub city -- a lot of conferences and events in the area, and it naturally draws a diverse, international crowd both to the city and to UCSF proper. 
- They really are trying to be decent about diversity, equity and inclusion, and for an institution of this size, they do well. UCSF has sued the federal gov't to protect the DACA program and are launching an anchor institution program to invest more in the local community. They're not perfect, but you could do a lot worse.
cons:
- Bureaucracy
- Cost of living here is just insane, and they don't compensate non-faculty enough for this (my salary is voluntarily supplemented by my supervisor, most are not). This includes cost of transportation, which is probably going to be close to an hour commute no matter where you live, and if you drive, you still pay out the nose for parking. 
- UC police are not an exception to the rule of police hassling POC who "don't belong" while doing absolutely nothing to prevent laptop theft and worse

review_title: One-dimensional workplace and generally does not value staff
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Leading health research institution if this matches your desire to do good. Offers good salaries and very good benefits that include a pension.
cons:
UCSF has a caste system, and, in general, everyone who is not a doctor or a professor is not respected for their expertise. Doctors and professors get all the privileges and respect, including private offices, etc. regardless of the kind of work they do.

Others are not respected for their knowledge and can be made to feel humiliated. Many highly skilled  staff give up contributing. There is no sense of teamwork where a project can benefit from different viewpoints and professions because the research environment champions single leaders (the people who get the grants) who are expected to call all the shots even when they know nothing about an area.

A lot of funding is based on grants and grants expire. Employment in those situations has an expiration date of at most 5 years, and most grants last for 1 year.

Although UCSF keeps putting up new buildings, very little money goes into maintenance. In the older buildings, it's pretty common to work in the middle of mouse infestations, cramped cubicles, and windowless rooms.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Great mentorship 
Livable wage 
Good benefits
cons: Vague responsibilities gives room for overloading work

job_title: Research Scientist in San Francisco, CA
pros: supportive environment, nice people, and great resources...
cons: I cannot think of any.

job_title: Office Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: -Great people to work with
cons: -Salary could be more for living in an expensive area

job_title: Practice Coordinator in San Francisco, CA
pros: Good company, good team, good management
cons: Remote work at the moment

job_title: Biomedical Engineer in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great atmosphere, gym, library, people
cons: Cost of living too high

job_title: Research Associate in San Francisco, CA
pros: Good for learning new skill set
cons: Lack of personal mentor ship

review_title: UCSF is not business as usual...it's a different world and plays by different rules.  You may end up in deep therapy.
job_title: Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: You have no other available choices. If you are a postdoc, Phd or MD.  Those are some good reasons.
cons: You may walk into a department from hell if you don't know what you're getting into. It's the luck of the draw. Professional career administrative support should think twice before entering any position related to academia.  Professors tend to be lazy, exhibit low work ethics, want you to bow down and basically become an indentured servant.  They are low on the ladder of communication skills and you are definitely expendable.  They have tenure -- you never will.  It's an ugly game to watch or be involved in.

job_title: Genetic Counselor Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Supportive management/colleagues
Strong commitment to patient care
cons: Hiring has not kept pace with growth

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in San Francisco, CA
pros: great science, collaborative environment, nice people
cons: compensation is bad, especially for living in SF.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in San Francisco, CA
pros: Good place to work at
cons: No major cons from what I have seen

review_title: Opportunity and growth within my career path, stability and overall satisfaction with salary and benefits.
job_title: Massage Services Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros:
UCSF is the 2nd largest employer in San Francisco so lots of opportunity. UCSF is a top ten medical center as well a top tier medical school and support cutting edge genetic and regenerative medicine research and all in one of the countries best city's to live.

Good benefits and a secure pension, free transportation between UCSF campuses and many other options for getting to and from work via transportation discount programs.

Other benefits include long term financial planning for your pension, life insurance as well as disability insurance and free legal advice if needed.

Many other helpful resources and wellness programs to help you stay healthy as well!
cons:
Slow to change and beholden to older technology.

Base salaries tend to be low for campus employees relative to the local economy.

The state government approves all annual merit increases and this is based on the states overall fiscal health and annual contribution to the University system so could and has lead to no annual increases across all campuses.

University regulations tend to be system wide and global sometimes creating a restrictive and inflexible work environment.

job_title: Assistant Professor of Marketing in San Francisco, CA
pros: very good and it's perfect salary
cons: nothing really it's really good

job_title: Or Scheduler in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great place to work for
cons: Very fast paced, commute to work

review_title: Great potential but a few unhappy puppies can spoil it.
job_title: Postdoctoral Scholar in San Francisco, CA
pros: Plentiful internal grants, good admin support for writing external grants, excellent core equipment.  Good healthcare.  If you're well trained, you can do good work here.
cons:
Despite excellent funding and resources, productivity suffers because of dissatisfied staff and internal competition.  In general, there are one too many unhelpful people, and the university needs to work on accountability, peer review, and staff satisfaction.  

If you work in the labs, there is a competitive atmosphere in some departments that, combined with poor oversight, sometimes breeds unethical behavior, which impedes collaboration.  This could be resolved with better management and ethics training.  Of course this will vary depending on department and lab. 

Postdoctoral pay uncompetitive, even by academic standards, compared with other local universities such as Stanford.  The NIH payscale is not an acceptable excuse for such low pay in a place like the Bay Area, and this needs to be fixed or UCSF will continue to lose talent to other universities with higher pay and better benefits.

job_title: Staff Accountant in Sharon, PA
pros: Can smoke at desk or at table
cons: Can sleep on job when you want

review_title: Personal experiences and job satisfaction vary significantly between departments
job_title: Analyst II in San Francisco, CA
pros: Very prestigious university; many educational opportunities through lunchtime and evening lectures; can be a moderately relaxed environment depending on one's department; job security if salary is funded by federal grants; promotions and salary increases can be attained if one is persistent enough (at least in my department)
cons: VERY bureaucratic and lots of red tape; takes forever to get anything accomplished when needing to deal with multiple departments; it feels like "one hand doesn't talk to the other"; Operational Excellence has served to further compartmentalize work functions and slow processes (such as grant management or finance reimbursement); researchers/clinicians do not have management skills and do not know how to coach or properly supervise their employees; salary is lower than industry standards (but not nearly as low as UC Berkeley); there are many ineffective employees who are not disciplined or released from employment, which further slows down the bureaucratic process; not much thought is given to employee workplace "living" (e.g. having a common lunch area rather than being forced to eat at one's desk); staff with written English skills too poor to coherently communicate via email (verbal language is fine); no bonuses

review_title: Not if you're actually good at your job.
job_title: Analyst II in San Francisco, CA
pros: You get to work with some of the most brilliant people in medicine and scientific research.
cons:
The worst administration you could possibly pair with the most brilliant doctors and researchers. I would say only a small percentage of administration is actually competent. Most of the people in administration don't know how to do their jobs. They're just not qualified. They need to be retrained or moved into positions that they're actually qualified for.

What happens at UCSF is that if you're one of the few people in administration who actually works and is competent, you're picking up the slack and doing work for 3-4 other people. This burns out people who are actually competent and work hard.

I'm hoping this all turns around because Sue Desmond-Hellmann is now the chancellor. I really like her messages and she seems to have a solid understanding of what needs to change. But, the people at the top who allowed administration to grow to this level of dysfunction are mostly still there and they're not going to change easily. It's going to take some time to turn the entire dysfunctional administration culture around.

review_title: It is a stressful time to be working at UC
job_title: Analyst IV in San Francisco, CA
pros: The positive side of working at UC is the benefits, and being part of a world-class research institute.
cons: There are major cut backs occuring at UC -- consolidations, "shared services," and other cost-cutting measures that involve substantial reductions in staffing, particularly of unrepresented employees.  The workloads have increased significantly, and it's made for an unhappy work environment for many  employees.  Additionally, there have been no significant raises for non-unionized staff in many years, and given that salaries are well below market rates, it may not be the first place to look for a job.  Significant changes will be starting July 1, 2013 to the pension plan as well, so lure of great benefits at UC is also changing.

review_title: Good training groud for postdoc at UCSF
job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in San Francisco, CA
pros: This is one of the top medical schools in the US and in the world. That says enough. You will obtain high recognition within the field once you are trained here. You will enjoy excellent facilities and have the opportunities to learn from excellent faculty members, meet and work with the brightest and most competent people with a wide variety of expertise. There is a pride being a UCSF alumni. Top companies, universities globally will all have your alumni, colleagues in the top positions, a mutual language is so easy to find.
cons: This is a university after all. If you want to start academic career after working here as postdoc or graduate student or even technician, it is a good choice.  It does provide industry collaboration opportunities, but only very limited management improvement opportunity. Some labs in the university operate somewhat industry style but do not have the appropriate industry management guidlines which makes it very difficult for employees to understand and cope with. People join with high expectation of the scientific training, but also want to learn management in real life.

job_title: Financial Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: UCSF has the best and brightest doctors in the United States and they are very nice people.  I enjoy working with all the doctors very much. UCSF also has great benefits and 13 holidays a year. My current supervisor and colleagues have a positive attitude and are very knowledgable about grants. I love my current department because the managers and staff are wonderful people.
cons: I was a Financial Analyst in Neurological Surgery for 18 months until I recently transferred to my new department.  The managers in Neurological Surgery didn't have any staff meetings and one on one meetings for the entire time I worked there because they sent emails all day long and never said hi to me. In addition, the managers excluded me from office events because I wasn't the favorite employee. That is why the turnover is very high in Neurological Surgery because many employees left for better opportunities. As a result, i left for the same job and received a raise in my new department.

job_title: Financial Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: The UC System is a great place to work! It's so big that there are countless career paths and opportunities. I love the mission of healthcare and medical research and this is a great place to be able to contribute to those causes in whichever way you're able to (I do it through financial planning and analysis). Even though we're a state entity, the base pay is relatively competitive (and the benefits are great!). Hard work is recognized and there are many opportunities for advancement, as long as you look for them and take the initiative.
cons: Because the system is so big, it can be a little intimidating. Also, because there's a culture of promoting from within, It can be a little hard to get a foot in the door. The pay can be good, but not the same as at local, VC fueled tech companies. Also, because we're a state entity, things like annual cost of living pay increases can change with the political tides.

review_title: Post-Doc Factory Unsuitable for Graduate Students
job_title: Graduate Student in San Francisco, CA
pros: Since UCSF cares only about grant money, their name is highly respected by funding agencies. It may be easier to get your grant approved here than at a less well-known school. Get an NSF grant your first year and then run with it to somewhere else (they'll tell you this isn't possible, but they're lying).
cons: Most graduate schools de-emphasize students' actual learning, teaching experience, and social life, which is made up for by the thrill of discovery and actually doing science. But UCSF's graduate program takes the cons to such an extreme that it can easily kill even the strongest enthusiasm for science. At UCSF graduate students are cheap skilled labor and absolutely nothing else. Expect no mentorship and only the most trivial of interaction with labmates. They boast about collaboration but it turns out that after rotations you're lucky if you're working with others at your bench, let alone the lab down the hall. UCSF might be suitable for post-docs or the most extreme of introverts, but if you're a graduate student and only normal science nerd levels of introvert, steer clear. Also, if you think non-translational (meaning non-medical) biology or any other science matters, you won't get along with anyone at this overgrown medical school.

review_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in Genentech Hall, Dept of Biochemistry and Biophysics
job_title: in San Francisco, CA
pros: UCSF Mission bay has labs in an "open lab" format with benches for 3 or more labs shared in a large space with a communal lunchroom and conference space that facilitates interactions between different labs. Location is served by numerous UCSF shuttles, a Mission Bay shuttle, as well as 2 Muni trains and a variety of public buses. Genentech hall has a lactation room.
cons: The IT department is lacking in some basic services which can slow down research. For example, there are effectively no site-licences for common research software like pymol or Matlab. In addition, while some core research facilities and equipment access is excellent, some are missing such as a protein purification core (everyone needs their own FPLC, etc).

review_title: Post-doctoral Fellowship-Excellent scientific resources but easy to get lost
job_title: Post Doctoral Researcher in San Francisco, CA
pros: If you want to be part of some of the latest and most interesting groundbreaking science (whatever your field of practice), then this is an excellent place to meet people and hone your craft. World class access to journals, excellent workshops on data tools, and subject matter experts all are part of this world.
cons: I can only speak as a post-doc working in behavioral health and as a post-doc your autonomy might be either too limited or be too unstructured. It can be hard to find that sweet spot at times and it's not a place where you should be if you don't like the instability of the grant funding process. Most non-clinicians live on soft money.

review_title: Low stress, low pay, lots of bureaucracy
job_title: Research Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros:
-Good benefits
-Not too stressful. There's a lot of work, but there are so many mediocre people here, that just showing up means you're a good employee.
-Once you're in the system, it seems like you're preferred for a lot of other UCSF jobs.
cons:
-Horrible HR. Slow and get the final say on everything.
-Low salaries compared to industry/private.
-Lots of turnover in some departments. I worked in two different departments and never had a direct supervisor last longer than 9 months. They either leave for other UC jobs or for industry because salaries are so low here. This means that you can never be sure the tasks you're responsible for today will be your responsibility in a month, or if you'll have additional duties on your plate. You sometimes get a stipend (a raise if you have a good dept) for additional duties, but more often not. Which leads me to...
-Heavy workload for not that much money. 
-Top-heavy.

job_title: Lab Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros:
-Days where there is hardly anything to do. Part of what I like about science jobs is that there are long stretches of nothing to do but there are weeks where I worked 12+ hours a day for a few weeks.
-If you don't like the place you are in, its pretty easy to hop departments
-beautiful campus and work environment, most of the buildings are new and have lots of space for taking lunch breaks
-Lots of upward mobility. Many people treated their lab manager job as a stepping stone to graduate or med school. Salary increased yearly pretty significantly to match experience
cons:
-As with most science and salary careers, you often work odd hours with no overtime. I had days where I stayed until midnight and weekends were necessary for my lab.
-Parking is terrible no matter what campus you are at
-Public transportation is equally as bad if you are not already in the city
-The work life balance needs to be fought for. Management will always push to work you harder unless you push back
-Vacations need to be planned very meticulously and well in advance (like months in advance)

job_title: Staff Research Associate III in San Francisco, CA
pros: The lab I worked for was really what made this job one of my favorites so far. They were like my family away from home. As long as we got our work done, we could take a long lunch or leave early every once in a while. Working at a world class research institute also led to six publications in 4 years. Plus I'm still being cited on new papers even though I left 2.5 years ago. There are also many opportunities to attend medical/health seminars and network with the medical school, receive scholarships for continuing education, and collaborate with other departments.
cons: As with any lab job, the work can get monotonous. I felt like I mastered most of my responsibilities after 1 year. But this also gave me more time to expand my role, improve procedures and protocols, organize, be involved in the grant writing process, and learn more about the research itself (not just the bench work). Because of this, I received a promotion from SRA I to SRA II after 1.5 years.

review_title: Did I walk into the comic strip Dilbert by mistake?
job_title: Decline to State in San Francisco, CA
pros: Benefits are good for less-than-full-time employees.
cons: As a corporation masquerading as a scholarly establishment, the emphasis is pretty obviously focused on keeping power at the top. Anyone below senior administrator is going to find out right away their input means exactly zero. incompetence and blind obedience is often promoted. God have pity on anyone with an original idea, as administration will smite thee down with a bolt of lightning. Thou shalt not question the wisdom of those On-High. There is a reason why the turnover rate in most positions is higher than at McDonald's... because you find out right away that nobody gives a rat's ass. Best one can do is keep your mouth shut, nod when told what to do, and look for a better job elsewhere. I know my supervisor is constantly asking me about work opportunities at my other job... he hasn't figured out he's the last person on earth I'd want to work with a job where I'm appreciated as an individual with ideas and originality.

review_title: A good place for work/life balance with limited advancement opportunities
job_title: Sra III in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great environment to acquire new skills and hear talks from leaders in the field.  Good benefits package.  Low stress work environment because deadlines are not usually a big issue.   Depending on the Principal Investigator, your input counts a lot.  Great work/life balance.
cons: Monetary compensation is low compared to private companies.  Advancement seems very difficult for non-PhD's.

review_title: It's good, however, I have had to bypass management in some instances (benefits, medical issues)
job_title: in San Francisco, CA
pros: Do have to say in some other areas my team has been supportive. I do feel safe working here and that is a major plus. The health benefits are also very good and on par with other universities. Parking is an ongoing problem for alot of people though, myself included.
cons: Each person's experience is different but it's not pleasant to receive emails from Management saying we need to cut costs and salaries while Faculty members still get raises.  Salary and experience are not always on par either among staff. I've seen where personal relationships with the Manager were factors of higher raises or position level.

review_title: Good place to start a public health career, but not necessarily to stay
job_title: Analyst III  in San Francisco, CA
pros: It has a very good reputation and brand.  Telecommuting options were VERY generous and flexible.
cons: This is not a good place for someone looking for steady career advancement unless they have a PhD.  For Masters-level professionals, there is little opportunity to advance, and little incentive to do so.  Because pay is largely based on equity to other peers in the same job position, there is no incentive to do exceptional work.  Seniority is the biggest determinant of salary increases or promotion.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Work at an institution with an important mission that actually contributes to humanity, surrounded by brilliant people who love what they do. If you are a physician, research scientist, or professor, I imagine it's a better environment than it is for academic non-faculty staffmembers.
cons: Facilities are old, there is too much broken-down furniture, small rooms, few windows. It's difficult to advance without changing departments or managers. Managers are not trained in management, so they don't always treat employees equally or fairly. Salaries are relatively low, if you've come from a corporate environment and you're not already a very high-level manager yourself.

job_title: Research Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Because they dont promote or give raises in the same dept, you can work one job for a little bit and then switch for a new job at a different dept at ucsf for a higher ranking/paying position and climb the ladder that way.

If you're ambitious and just starting out in research/healthcare, it's okay job to get experience.
cons: Poor managers. Does not reward hard work. To get a raise at UCSF, you have to leave the department. No career development. The university is top heavy, too many managers and directors. No organization. Poor on boarding for new staff.  Low team morale.

job_title: Project Coordinator in San Francisco, CA
pros: Highly intelligent	 people, generally warm and important research being done. Mentorship and encouragement of students, faculty and staff. There are many opportunities to get involved with interesting projects and programs, but one must know the right people and have the support and encouragement to do so which is always the case.
cons: Dispersed, commuting very expensive and time consuming. Should provide telecommuting options for those who travel long hours. A lot of favoritism - there is a ‘clique’ going on among a certain level of management and staff. Income not competitive in the SF Bay Area - retention issues in some departments. There are those who are placed in positions of authority and supervision who are not capable of managing staff.

job_title: Administrative Analyst I in San Francisco, CA
pros: I like working in Pediatrics doing administrative work for a team of doctors, it gives me a good feeling to know I'm contributing to heal children and their families indirectly. This job makes use of the skills I've used my whole career and I feel appreciated. The benefits are good, mandatory retirement plan, cheap health insurance cost for a good plan, vacation and sick pay, and convenient location with parking.
cons: The pay is lower than the last jobs I've had and I don't think comparable with salary in the private sector. The bureaucracy in getting things approved through all the departments and to actually deal with so many people and take so much time to get things done if it involves different departments. Sometimes so slow to effect the solution you need.

review_title: No thinking outside the box here
job_title: Analyst IV in San Francisco, CA
pros:
The people who work here are are passionate about the research they do and/or clinical care they provide to patients and it is exciting to be a part of this community; 
Having UCSF as a place of employment is great to have on your resume.
cons: Due to budget (and therefore personnel) cuts, the workload has become overwhelming and unsustainable. Management expects exempt employees to work hours beyond what is reasonable and staff are burned out and depressed.  To add to the sense of disgruntlement, there have been no pay raises for non-unionized staff for four years.

review_title: Program Manager at Healthforce Center at UCSF
job_title: Program Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros:
-UCSF benefits
-Can be good if you find the right department within UCSF, but I wouldn't recommend the Healthforce Center at UCSF
cons:
-Awful director and leadership at Healthforce Center
-Turnover rate has been over 50% in the last 2+ years due to poor leadership
-Morale is low and there is little trust amongst employees
-Leadership prioritizes faculty members over staff (i.e., faculty are more valuable than staff members)
-Leadership does not seek input from employees about their opinions or needs
-Director starts relationships with employees as if we have something to prove before she grants basic respect and trust to individuals
-Director is completely oblivious to the negative impact her poor leadership has on the staff

This place used to be decent to work for when the founder was around but after he retired, the new director is terrible; it's amazing how a center that focuses on leadership development can be so terrible at practicing it. Do yourself a favor and avoid applying for a job here; there's a reason why they have many job posts listed- can't retain talented employees.

job_title: in San Francisco, CA
pros: UCSF has a very different work environment compared to the other UC's, due to the fact that students there are in the health sciences and research graduate programs only and because UCSF operates a hospital.  This translates to a professional work environment where employee input is generally sought out and put into practice.  UCSF attracts leaders in the field, and this creates a refreshing environment where many are really passionate about their work and care about the surrounding community.  And the students there are fantastic.
cons: UCSF is spread out all over the city. There is a decent shuttle system connecting all of the campuses. Employees have offices in one location, but meetings and events can be on different campuses, so traveling to and from can sometimes be a pain (unless you are located on the main campus).

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in San Francisco, CA
pros: UCSF attracts some of the most brilliant scientists, students, doctors, and researchers in the world. The atmosphere is friendly but with very high expectations. I was overworked  (60+ hrs a week) but learned a ton and adored my colleagues. There is endless opportunity for growth, learning, mentorship, and building collaborative relationships across departments.  UCSF definitely has a few things that I would change but overall  I would recommend it as a workplace.
cons: UCSF, in recent years, has had little to no raises & pay is way less than similar industry research jobs. I ended up switching to tech (user research)  to increase my salary and improve my work-life balance.

review_title: Attention animal care workers: DO NOT work here if you care for animals!
job_title: Laboratory Animal Technician in San Francisco, CA
pros:
- Decent health benefits and retirement 
- UPTE union (for research employees) is very helpful
- Stable pay
- A lot of paid vacation and sick time
- Most research staff is professional and pleasant to work with 
-Predictable work schedules
cons:
- Majority of animal care employees do not care for the animals 
- Hazardous and dangerous work conditions. Staff are expected to work very quickly, which will compromise safety, as well as animal welfare
- Low pay for bay area
- Current benefits may be good, but UC regents keep wanting to cut and underpay employees
- Extremely Bureaucratic work environment
- Many employees in the LARC department are very anti-LGBT

job_title: Postdoctoral Scholar in San Francisco, CA
pros: UCSF has an excellent reputation and there are some wonderful people who work here.
cons:
The pay for most does not take into account the cost of living in San Francisco.

The PIs are not trained, or encourage to train, as managers so their people skills are almost non-existent.  They offer little or no career development advice, instead they are paranoid about getting funding.  Staff in the labs have no way to voice concerns, as their success is coupled to that of their PIs.

HR is slow and often ineffective.  Operational excellent has severely damaged the personal touch of UCSF.

Too many reports of bullying, sexual harassment, racism, homophobia for a progressive institution.  PIs seem to be able to bully etc without fear of repercussion.  The "little man" takes all of the blame.  Senior PIs bully their way out of complying with university policy.

review_title: Great place for research and medicine. Not so great if you're a staff member.
job_title: Administrative Analyst II in San Francisco, CA
pros: Very smart people to work with. The opportunity to feel really good about the effect of your work. It's easy to believe in the mission of advancing health.
cons: Salary remains pretty stagnant after hire. Negotiate your starting wage well. Doctors tend to manage their groups and doctors are not trained in management. Although great people work there, they are not celebrated and there is little attention, time or resources devoted to growing talent within the organization (at the staff level).

job_title: Staff Research Associate III in San Francisco, CA
pros: I previously worked in industry, and I have found that at UCSF I was quickly introduced to a wider variety of techniques and skills than in prior employment. The work is generally interesting and the postdocs and intelligent and energetic. I find that most staff members work regular hours and the benefits are good.
cons: Job stability is a problem, since it is difficult to sustain reliable grant funding. The pay tends to be lower than in industry. Sometimes the principle investigators are less focused, quirkier and capable of managing than the research directors in industry, although this statement can be disputed, I am sure.

review_title: UCSF - a world class scientific institution but do a lot of research before taking a position
job_title: Development in San Francisco, CA
pros: UCSF is a world-class academic life sciences research institution and medical center, with amazing discoveries made by wonderful scientists every day. I am proud to work for such a great institution and have the greatest respect for my scientist colleagues.
cons: The administrative and non-scientific staff (accounting, finance, development) are poorly led, with cronyism, 'social promotion,' and workplace bullying being rampant. Poor to no management training or accountability leading to most of the good people leaving within a year or two -- often for Stanford! Before taking a position, you *must* carefully research the department and the rest of the team.

review_title: UCSF should work to attract and invest in keeping the best quality employees.
job_title: Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: The University of California offers a great reputation as a uality institution. Serves community. Leading research institution.
cons: Poor pay scale; bureaucratic environment, unhealthy and cramped working conditions. It is dependent upon the state budget for much of its funding, and the state of California is cutting even the most essential functions.

review_title: Ok experience in reproductive science lab
job_title: Research Associate in San Francisco, CA
pros:
- PI was amazing and inspiring
- Well-stocked and up to date equipment/lab facility
- Friendly employees in the UCSF Mt. Zion campus (working in other labs)
- Great location
- Fair pay for what it is
- Opportunity to teach newer research associate
cons:
- Lab supervisor was condescending and terrible to work with
- Last minute work schedule - unpredictable and tough to plan ahead
- Job was temporary due to their funding schedule
- Lack of grant funding
- Unclear directions from lab supervisor - kept me guessing and did not set me up for success
- Left all responsibility on me to guide/teach less experienced associate
- Major lack of communication across entire lab, from PI to supervisor to research associates
- At the end of the day its a lab job - lots of time on your feet doing repetitive tasks

review_title: Definitely the best job I ever had.
job_title: Administrative Assistant III  in San Francisco, CA
pros: It has excellent benefits, and, at least in the department where I work, a very nice atmosphere.  That was not true in the first position I had here.  There, the employees had a lot of conflict.  This was made worse by having a boss who showed favortism towards some, based mainly on race.  He has since left UCSF.  I was passed over for a promotion twice based on race.  After the second time, I filed a grievance, which helped lead to me getting my current position, where I am much happier.  Within the department I am in now, we have strong leadership, and a very congenial work environment.
cons: It is very large, and can be very bureacratic at times.

review_title: UCSF is a boring, but reliable place to work
job_title: Administrative Assistant III in San Francisco, CA
pros: At UCSF you get a lot of vacation days (holiday and other). Also, it is a pretty relaxed environment. A good part of working here is that after 6 months, your job is pretty secure. Also, you get a raise every 9 months or so. It is also nice that you get discounts on a lot of things such as zipcars.
cons: It is hard for me to see a career coming out of working here, so in some ways I feel like I am wasting my time. UCSF seems like the type of place where people come and go all the time. Within my first month working, I saw several people leave for better positions elsewhere. A lot of people just sit around doing nothing all day. It seems like a lot of money is being wasted here.

job_title: Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: If you care about Education, Medicine, Research, and San Francisco; then UCSF is a place to have a job in that field.  You will have a chance to encounter a lot of different, and often disparate, operational business and office models.
cons: It IS a "non-profit", which wags to the donors demands, despite the actual demands of operations in an organization that size.  Job expectations often exceed the demands of for-profit equivelants. That action is not based on medical, security, or safety urgency, but simply bad policy institutional conflicts with contracts/grants needs,  school and department conflicts.  If you hope for access

review_title: Great place to work for, but expect lots of bureaucracy.
job_title: Programmer Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: The benefits are great, especially the shuttles. Staff are nice, and the physicians are generally good people who you get to know on a first-name basis. It's a prestigious place to work for, and is a top-notch research organization.
cons: Huge loss of morale in IT. Everyone was consolidated under a single umbrella called Operational Excellence, and had to re-apply for their job under a new central IT organization. UCSF is also not competitive in salary due to all the tech companies in the Bay Area, so retention is low for well qualified employees. There is little to no upward mobility, and salaries are stagnant because they don't want to raise them across the board.

review_title: Great working environment with low pay.
job_title: Staff Research Associate III in San Francisco, CA
pros: I have really enjoyed working with mostly smart scientist. There are always exceptions of course, but I am overall impressed witht the scientific minds at UCSF. There is access to many great reserch facilities, such as the Nikon Imaging Center. Researchers are generally working on very interesting projects. Fortunatly UCSF offers a good benifits package.
cons: There are a lot of people leaving UCSF research due to very low salaries for staff scientists and post docs. Of course, working environments are drastically different from one lab to another. There are some group leaders that do a very poor job of managing their people or treating their people respectfully, though this is usually not the case. There are issues with people not being able to get promotions or raises due to Union restrictions, which is a bit ridiculous.

review_title: A large, cumbersome institution; depending on your Dept./team, etc., it could be awesome or pure frustration.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Benefits are good and at least in my case the work/life balance was solid; the majority of your co-workers will be great. Amazing research and innovation in the life sciences.
cons: A huge organization which is not very agile; it takes tremendous effort to move anything forward. Inevitable politics and egos. A sizeable number of middle managers could be let go and it would not be noticed - plus the $$ saved would be considerable. Little to no training for administrative staff.

job_title: in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great Benefits, generally speaking one is able to maintain good work/life balance, although that has varied from department to department for me.  interesting work, great minds work here.
cons: If you work in a department without a lot of money (grants, donations, infrastructure) you can find yourself running ragged trying to get all the tools you need to perform your job well. Depending on the campus you may work in an office in the basement, with no natural light or ventilation. The office in which I worked (on those few SF days that reached into upper 80s) it could be hotter in the office than outside and you have to work in oppressive heat. If you work in a unionized position you can pretty much forget about ever getting a raise, they're constantly locked in "discussions" with the powers that be of UCSF.

job_title: Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros:
-Great health benefits, lots of time off
-Great retirement pension plan if you stay there for the minimum of 5 years
-If you have a good manager, I'm sure it could be a great place to work.  Your career is basically in the hands of your manager and how assertive you are about getting a promotion or a raise.
cons: There was a lack of leadership in my specific department.  Research your division, the managers, as well as the faculty to know what you will be dealing with.  There are complicated rules that will limit your promotions and salaries.  Make sure you are aware of the policies before you accept a job offer.

job_title: Registered Nurse in San Francisco, CA
pros: Teaching institution, you learn from everyone around you no matter what your position is. Great benefits, great training, and team atmosphere.
cons: Vacation bank is scarce. Only 2.5 weeks per year allowed if you work 40hrs per week. Even less allowed if you work less than that.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in San Francisco, CA
pros:
World-class physicians doing cutting-edge research
Casual culture
Nice co-workers
Flexible schedule
cons:
Inadequate training for middle management
Low pay
Lots of turnover
Difficult to advance or transfer departments
Lack of communication between University departments often hinders progress 
HR is very secretive about the process for requesting a pay increase

review_title: An ideal employer that provided a stepping stone to further education in an environment supportive of learning.
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in San Francisco, CA
pros: UCSF provided good benefits (health insurance, time off, retirement plans) and an ideal learning environment for a new graduate seeking additional education in the future. The team of health care providers and managers that I worked for expected a high level of performance, but also provided support and opporunities to learn and improve. Excelling at the job resulted in recognition and promotions.
cons: The environment may very much depend on your leadership team. At times bureaucracy can be a barrier to advancement.  Change and processes are very slow. Turnover in research teams is high.

job_title: Staff Research Associate II in San Francisco, CA
pros:
-Amazing people! Everyone who comes here is mind-bogglingly intelligent, driven, passionate, and kind! From the graduate students to the staff to the doctors/nurses/medical professionals, everyone here is a delight to work with.
-UCSF does a lot to advance the life sciences fields. You can see the direct effects we have on the community.
-Good benefits--health, dental, vision, etc.
cons:
-You have to pay for gym access, and its not cheap!
-The university is split into multiple campuses than are spread over San Francisco. Although there are free shuttles that regularly run between the campuses all day long, this commute between campuses is something to take into account when planning out your day
-Ridiculously expansive city to live in. Not anything to do with UCSF in particular, but the extremely high cost of living in San Francisco makes everything a little harder.

review_title: Smart people, beautiful and fun city, not enough money or time
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in San Francisco, CA
pros: The research environment is really stimulating and collaborative. There are always great seminars and new postdocs coming from other places to befriend and/or learn from. The faculty are all really passionate about doing good science, and it makes for a great training environment. In addition, there are numerous bay area science & technology events to attend.
cons: It is incredibly expensive to live in San Francisco and UCSF does not account for the cost of living - salaries here for postdocs and graduate students are the same as they are in Nashville, TN, for example. Also, because the training environment is so top-notch, and the state of funding in science is so dire, many PIs are stressed and many people work 60-90 hours a week.

review_title: Analyst I - EA to Department Chair
job_title: Analyst I in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great mission. Great work environment - you're surrounded by prominent scientists working to cure and prevent disease. Always something going on - farmers market, lectures, films. Opportunity to get involved in projects beyond the typical EA tasks, but depending on the faculty member, this might take initiative on your part. Access to medical journals. Great benefits. Great leadership.
cons: Few opportunities for staff to engage in professional development. You really have to advocate for yourself to get this. Very difficult to get a raise or promotion if you stay in the same group/dept. Many "lifers" who don't appear to be interested in working hard or improving things. Very bureaucratic. Low pay.

job_title: ___ Assistant I in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Start 3 weeks of vacation per year
Full benefits for 50‰ and above
Excellent job security
Fantastic Benefits package
Great opportunities for career advancement
cons: Because there is good job security, there's a lot of 'dead wood' who have been there for years, can't get rid of them so they make everybody's work life around them miserable. If you are homophobic, do NOT work here because a great many of your co-workers are either open or closed homosexual. Never had an issue with it but can see it if someone does.

job_title: Staff Research Associate II in San Francisco, CA
pros:
The brand name of UCSF. Whatever you do after this working at UCSF will always be an advantage while seeking your next job. 
Getting to stay in the Bay area with good weather and other job opportunities. Best place to stay if you are even remotely interested in starting up later.
cons:
Considering the living expenses in San Francisco and the Bay, the salary is terribly low.You will have no savings at all. 
UCSF does not pay for any professional development courses you wish to do or that will help in your professional growth.
There is no option of getting housing at UCSF for research associates and staying in the city is ridiculously expensive.

review_title: Huge campus, great students, weak managers
job_title: Student Academic Affairs Officer III in San Francisco, CA

review_title: Engaging and open environment with actual achievement instead of grandiosity
job_title: Senior Clinical Research Coordinator in San Francisco, CA

I also dont feel like i have to stress out about the little details like being a bit late on days when you have nothing scheduled or occasionally working if u have family other domestic priorities.
cons: The high cost of living in the surrounding areas makes surviving around here  a challenge

review_title: A great place to work if you're in the life sciences or medical fields.
job_title: Graduate Student in San Francisco, CA

The faculty here are some of the best and brightest in the world, and the research is absolutely cutting edge. There's also the benefit of getting to live in San Francisco while you're here.
cons: It can be a high - pressure environment, depending on whom you're working for. Additionally, if you choose to leave the life science or medical fields, the UCSF name might not carry as much prestige for those who aren't necessarily in the know.

review_title: overall a good place to work; but if you're staff ...and eager...you may feel stuck with the lack of variety.
job_title: Analyst I in San Francisco, CA

ex: whistle blower program, very politically correct environment, extracurricular activities.

-again, many jobs posted, but if you're staff, many of those jobs available are all the same!

job_title: Staff Research Associate in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great place to work when you're a new grad. Lots of opportunities to train on different projects, responsibilities are given quickly, and there are learning/lecture opportunities. Also, if you're interested in professional school, its a great place to make contacts that can help you get admitted!
cons: The pay is not competitive, but it is run by a government that's in a lot of financial trouble. Probably about 10-20% less than what you would make in the private sector. But, if you're a new grad, this is a great place to start. There's not very much room for advancing since many titles rely on the number of degrees you have.

review_title: Great place for young scientists to learn!
job_title: Staff Research Associate I in San Francisco, CA
pros: Lots of events and seminars with prominent speakers to attend.  Get the sense that the faculty really care about the research associates/analysts/graduate students/postdocs in their lab.  Faculty are attentive to concerns of their lab members.  I feel like I have a project that could someday lead to better prevention and treatment of patients - so I feel very motivated to keep working.
cons: As is the case with any large university/corporation, there is a lot of bureaucracy to get through before one can get started with doing any experiments.  The pay is not great given that I have to pay rent in San Francisco.

job_title: Administrative Assistant III in San Francisco, CA
pros: Huge university, many different departments if you don't like the one you're in, good benefits.  Some jobs are unionized, some not. Interesting perks, like free lunchtime concerts, presentations on different topics, etc.
cons:
Bureaucracy is cast in stone.  Hard for mgmt to reward employees with raises, given set job titles with set salaries, etc.  
Working with doctors, surgeons, post-docs, can be difficult depending on their specific personalities. Some are quite demeaning, even bullying, to staff members. Since they 'bring in the bucks', they generally get away with it.

job_title: Programmer/Analyst in San Francisco, CA

Health Sciences is the mission; generally a place that makes the world better.
Good benefits and job stability.

Unless you are in a union, or are frequently promoted (or change jobs), 
your salary will eventually become ridiculous.   Even highly-rated employees
see a typical annual increase below 0.25% on average.  My salary is less
in 2010 than it was in 2007.

job_title: Associate Specialist III in San Francisco, CA

cons: Expect to be hired at the bottom of your position's pay scale with no room for bargaining. No PhD = Unbreakable glass ceiling in doing any academic work. I was Project Director for a huge research grant, literally did all of the work, without credit, PI plagiarized the hell out of my work before I could publish. Hold your cards close to your chest, and choose your PI *very* wisely.

review_title: Good environment for science if you are  in the right department with the right boss.

review_title: Helen Diller cancer center -- great community, mediocre resources
job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in San Francisco, CA
pros: The Helen Diller Cancer Center at Mission Bay has dozens of excellent labs, all thematically organized around cancer.  The building also hosts excellent seminar speakers during the fall/winter/spring.  It's easy to collaborate, learn a technique, or borrow supplies from your colleagues.
cons: Like the other UC campuses, UCSF doesn't have a lot of money.  The core facilities in particular seem underfunded compared to Stanford.  There is also a lot of bureaucratic red tape that slows things down any time you want to do something, like hire a tech or apply for a grant.  Postdocs are paid the NIH minimum salary, but that's not much compared to the cost of living in SF.

job_title: Visiting Assistant Professor in San Francisco, CA
pros: You get to live in San Francisco.  Flexible schedule in research.  When you actually get to focus on the research and the ideas, that part is terrific, it just is too overshadowed by everything else.
cons: Unrealistically high expectations of junior people, combined with fake mentorship, no departmental support, and no financial security.  If you plan on having children, writing grants every evening and weekend is not good for family life.  You are a throw-away at UCSF.  It's a "Don't let the door hit you on the way out... yawn, you only brought in one million?"... kind of place.  When you bring in new partnerships and funds, they want your contacts, but they don't help you build any.  The administrative reorganizations have overburdened everyone, there is more work, fewer services, and no real efficiency gains.

review_title: Great place to work if you have MD or PhD after your name.
job_title: _____Assistant (Really, 'blank' Assistant) in San Francisco, CA

review_title: Great name, and wonderful people, but structure can be difficult at times.
job_title: Senior Clinical Research Coordinator in San Francisco, CA

job_title: Research Assistant in San Francisco, CA
