review_title: Fantastic, Depending on which department you get
job_title: Administrative Assistant III in San Francisco, CA
pros:
-Excellent Benefits
-Very Tech Savvy
-Lots of Opportunities for Professional Growth

As a disclaimer, while I had a wonderful experience in my department, many people have suffered horror stories at UCSF. It's impossible to give a rating to the entire institution, as your experience will vary depending on which campus and department you're in. Parnassus tends to have many more politics and personality issues, whereas the campuses are generally more easygoing. Again, this is a blanket statement and can be totally off depending on who you get, but it's typically true.

My department was located at San Francisco General, which is the most inclusive and least political campus (although they still exist here, just not to the degree of Parnassus). I was very fortunate to work in a major clinical department in which I had the support and respect of everyone in the clinical and admin staff, from the bottom to the top. It truly did feel like a loving family, and is extremely rare anywhere in this world but there are some departments at UC that are really doing it right. 

Starting pay is usually okay (not great, but serviceable), but depends entirely on how "flush" the department you join is. Some have more money (Surgery, Anesthesia, Medicine) and some have less (Podiatry, Otolaryngology, Optometry).
cons:
-Raises take a while to go through. You're supposed to receive fifty cents or so every six months, but instead you usually get a buck and some change every couple years, so that can be frustrating. If you feel you've been more than puling your weight, though, you can apply for a merit increase (an unscheduled raise) or a step-up, which is going up in title.

-Some people can be very unhelpful. There's a tendency among some that if you ask for complex help or for them to teach you how to do anything that even vaguely relates to their job, they believe you're "trying to steal their job" and they become very difficult to work with. You mainly see this in departments that have heavy politics and poor management. Departments that cross-train and have a good collegial atmosphere typically don't have this problem and are much easier to work in.

-Unions can be very obstructive if you hold a union position and are trying to advance in your career. While claiming to get your back in everything, they will do whatever they can to fight your "upgrade" to a non-union position, as they don't want to lose your membership (and dues, I'm sure). Many union employees who want to advance typically have to apply for a vacantAnalyst position in their department, or move to a different department, which is unfortunate if you're in a department that you really enjoy.

review_title: Great, lots of opportunities, a bit spread out, slow HR
job_title: Postdoctoral Scholar in San Francisco, CA
pros: There are numerous opportunities to attend seminars and events, which are emailed to you daily. There are a lot of top people to potentially collaborate with. You are given 24 days off and 12 sick days per year.
cons: Because there are multiple campuses, not all of the seminars and opportunities are nearby. HR took a while to enter me into the system, and they can be slow. Most likely your relationship with your boss will be awkward enough that there will be unspoken pressure to not really take all 36 days off.

review_title: Ideal for some, not for all.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: UCSF is a fantastic employer when it comes down to benefits and long-term longevity and stability. Great working folks all around if you surround yourself with those individuals. Excellent work-life balance and I give kudos for the engagement the university tries to attempt on the Campus side of things vs. Medical Center side. In my role, I know I was able to touch the majority of the university because of what the services my department provides for the entire community whether they consciously know it or not.
cons:
- Politics: if you are involved with more senior levels of management constantly, it is a nightmare. In my management capacity, I was still being told to act on things in a certain manner that is detrimental to budgetary constraints, but told to do it anyways. Things you want to make better/more efficient is essentially hindered because it doesn't meet their expectations, even though it would remove confusion and barrier of entry for the services. I have a saying-- its the "UCSF way" even though UCSF has no clue on best practices by hiring great outside talent.

- Pay; If you want to be paid like you live in the bay area, good luck. You take the hit here and your pay is literally based on a combination of your experience, your manager's pay and your subordinate's pay. You have to be right in the middle, and make sure you don't step on anyone's toes because that's not equitable. BTW, its definitely not equitable that the director's pay is 2x yours.

- Colleagues - there is definitely the mentality that you are here to collect your check, go home, and retire in 20 years or so. There is no drive or ambition to make the university better, even if you try, you end up in the perils of university politics because no one wants to do more than what they feel like doing. And in succession, forget any upward mobility.

-Lack of coordination: if you work for the campus side like in this review, you are the scraps. You are not UCSF Health/UCSF Medical Center. You don't matter. You don't have money nor resources. You fight for everything you need/want while UCSF Medical Ctr/UCSF Health basks in the glory.

-University employees: I have never been disrespected by own employees in my life like the way these folks suck the blood out of your soul. I deal with the most uptight, obnoxious, uptight, privileged people because they feel that I owe them something. So much so, I've called university police on these very people multiple times which is crazy because you would think, this is a work environment,  things are dealt civilly, but to call on your own police department to deal with privileged UC employees is definitely not normal. I don't tell you how to do your job, so you definitely shouldn't tell me how to do mine. Stay in your lane, be humble.

-UCSF Values: If you make it known that you have culture and values, its really disheartening to try and enforce those values during disciplinary hearings on black & white cases with UCSF Values, just to see the determinator throw that out the window and decide something else.

review_title: Better to retire at UC than start your career here!
job_title: Analyst I in San Francisco, CA
pros: The retirement package and health benefits are the best reasons to work at UCSF. It is also a great place to be employed when you want to slow down, take more time off, spend more time with your family.
cons: The compensation is not at market value, especially for those who are entry or mid level or are coming from a for-profit agency or business.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Smart, dedicated and high achieving people. Decent benefits.  A mission that feels important.
cons: You can get the best annual reviews possible, but don't expect a promotion, or raise or good work-life balance. What you will get is more and more work and less and less support to do it. When someone leaves their job, they won't hire a new person, they just make someone left behind do two people's (or more) job. And pay here is crap.

review_title: it really depends on the department you work in
job_title: Event Planner in San Francisco, CA
pros: large company, can move around if you find you are unhappy in a department. its so large that its hard to get a handle on things from a management perspective. they do give reviews on time. some good minor recognition. good discounts around sf
cons: super bureaucratic, anyone who isn't a doctor is treated like an idoit. accounting is really backwards. expenses are paid whenever they get around to it. you have to fight for everything. HR is there to protect them, not to help employees. if you know someone high up, you can get anything passed

review_title: If you're considering graduate school, this is a great place to gain experience and exposure to the healthcare field.
job_title: Study Coordinator in San Francisco, CA
pros: Exposure to bright minds and innovative ideas within the healthcare field.  (Your individual work experience, however, will vary from department to department).
cons: Kind of like our health care system, UCSF seems a little fragmented, with students, residents, and a lot of staff moving on every few years.  There are some people who spend most of their career at UC, however.

review_title: Political minefield -- average employee doesn't have a prayer
job_title: Analyst II in San Francisco, CA
pros:
* Institution highly regarded in cutting edge health research
* Patients have a good experience  there 
* Opportunity to work with highly intelligent people
* No expectation of overtime; minimal effort acceptable
* Good benefits
cons:
* Overall, a very employee unfriendly place
* Zero career path
* No raises if you're not in a union
* Politics are off the charts - nearly impossible to be on the winning side
* Your performance as an employee is irrelevant; you will never see a pay raise whether you do your job well or poorly
* Highly bureaucratic

review_title: Great university with lots of upward mobility.
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in San Francisco, CA
pros: A challenging environment, lots of ways to collaborate with other investigators and their teams, and easy to move from team to team to find a right fit.
cons: Compensation is low, but is on par with the rest of the industry. Most PIs expect you to work more than 40hr/wk and to be very dedicated to what you are studying, although this is not necessarily a Con for all.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: UCSF is a big sprawling place but one of its chief attractions is that most people have a positive attitude and many people are exceptionally talented.
cons:
San Francisco may be a tourist destination but it is extremely expensive, traffic is terrible, and the city has a huge problem with homeless people and drug addicts. 

UCSF, being part of UC as a whole, does not necessarily reward its employees for good work, but rather for the number of people they manage. If you do not join a department with a clear path above you, you may get stuck in a career dead end.

job_title: Postdoctoral Scholar in San Francisco, CA
pros: Pros: world-class scientists, excellent technology, attention to professional development.
cons: Compared to similar-level universities (e.g. Stanford): rigid hierarchical structure, especially in medically-oriented departments. Remarkably little collaboration; some labs unnecessarily competitive to the point that it interferes with scientific advancement. Some professors give little freedom to their lab members. Promotion, especially from postdoc to faculty, often appears to depend on personal connection to a big-name professor and not on the relevant skills. Diversity is celebrated on paper, but faculty in the vast majority of departments are not diverse at all.

review_title: Working with labmates and the PI is great
job_title: SRA I in San Francisco, CA
pros: Working with  the people immediate around you is great  and many people  are  open  to providing new learning opportunities- especially if you're a fresh bio  grad working in  the lab.
cons: The pay is okay, I  guess. You  wouldn't want to keep going with this  salary  for  years  though. The admin is bloated and constantly hands off their  duties to another person until it comes full circle.

review_title: Fantastic Graduate Program with supportive environment for students and postdocs.
job_title: Graduate Student Research Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros: UCSF has consistently top-rated graduate and professional programs, gets a lot of NIH funding, and grad program admins/program coordinators try to help students with the difficulties of grad school and living in expensive SF. Student health is excellent, accessible and efficient.
cons: The bureaucracy is huge and sometimes impenetrable. No undergrad students means very little student programming, UCSF housing is at market rate, and there's not a huge sense of community, especially at the Mission Bay campus.

review_title: Excellent Place to Grow Your Career, But Highly Competitive!
job_title: Administrative Director in San Francisco, CA
pros:
-Great retirement plan (one of the best I've ever seen)
-4 weeks PTO per year (+13 holidays). The longer you work here, the more PTO you get. Especially if you are in a management position
-Networking opportunities for advancing your careers are tremendous (but you have to do the work. Nobody is going to just approach you. You only get what you put into it)
-Pay is decent. Opportunity for annual 10-15% bonus through management incentive plan
cons:
-Parking SUCKS. (Sorry, but it's the truth) Highly recommend you never buy a car if you live in the city of San Francisco. Save yourself the headache and peace of mind. Take it from someone who has one.
-Cost of living in SF is beyond ridiculous. It's insane. You like paying $4000+ for 1-bedroom apartment rental? You like paying $300+ a month for parking? You like $12 coffees and $15 ice creams? You like spending $13 on lunch every day? Then this is the place for you! Welcome.
-This is a highly competitive environment with very intelligent people. Please remember that UCSF is one of the top medical schools and hospitals/health systems in the country and the world. So it can be very challenging to get into the system and then (even harder) move up within the ranks. You really need to know the right people to keep moving up in your career, or you will simply become another needle in the haystack. There are over 20,000+ people working here, so you need to put the time in to develop relationships with the key players that run this organization (fyi, this is only advice for those who want to pursue a management track). Don't complain about how some are more lucky than others. Use your brain. You make your OWN luck in life. Focus. Put in the time and energy, and you will reap the rewards.
-If you do get promoted, please keep in mind that UCSF imposes a 25% pay raise cap on their employees. Which means that you cannot earn more than 25% raise of your previous salary each year without UCSF Board of Reagents Approval.  Since salaries often eat up the majority of any company's costs, they do this to control their costs. You can beat this if you provide solid evidence why you deserve more, but it's not an easy thing to beat.
- Pay could be better. But lets be honest, everybody wishes they made more money no matter where you work. It doesn't matter how much we make. What's more important is how you save your money through focused discipline and spend wisely throughout the years. Always pay yourself first. Always put yourself first. Never throw money away on stupid girlfriends/boyfriends, credit cards, lavish cars, overpriced trips, and you will be ok. Enjoy your life today, but be smart. Live within your current means  and plan for tomorrow too. And always pay down your student loans as QUICKLY as possible. Those things are absolute death traps.

review_title: Pretty good as an employer but sloooow
job_title: Analyst V in San Francisco, CA
pros: Varied jobs throughout the system and can gain much experience.
cons: 10% of people working too hard to cover for the other 90%. Slow to react, too many chiefs not enough Indians.  Admin often too afraid to stand up and make the right decision if they think its going to be met with resistance.

job_title: in San Francisco, CA
pros: In the UCSF ambulatory clinics there is a high level of physician clinical skill and nursing skill and Manager committment.
cons:
Two disparate groups (Medical Center & Campus) with different agendas oversee the ambulatory clinics.  There is poor, high level, leadership and poor coordination between these two groups, leading to less than optimal clinical operations and patient care. 
There is an extreme amount of physician hubris (reminiscent of the 70’s & 80’s) which sometimes interferes with patient care and is not conducive to a collaborative or supportive work environment.

review_title: Exciting Research. I have been working at UCSF full-time (More than 15 years)
job_title: Director, Clinical Research in Sausalito, CA
pros: Innovative progressive institution. Fabulous place to excel in cutting medical research,  great benefits.
cons: Low compensation for comparable position outside UCSF and slow and limited career growth potential.  Hard to get raises, even with exemplary reviews and stellar job performance. Must ask and be proactive due to it being a public institution and the bureaucracy, politics, and constant budget issues.

review_title: UCSF can attract the best people; but it can't keep them
job_title: Administrator in San Francisco, CA
pros: Decent salary, good benefits, interesting and meaningful work, smart folks. Everything you'd want in a job.
cons:
The university frequently hires people who are really knowledgable, but have no management or leadership skills, into management and leadership positions. So, they're all smart, and some are nice, but really awful at the work they're being paid to do.

 If you have the misfortune of working under one of these people, it will be like slamming your head against a wall every day.  You'll spend your day trying to get them to see a problem and ask them to take steps to fix it, until one day you just give up and leave.

job_title: Postdoctoral Scholar in San Francisco, CA
pros: Apart from being one of the best institution to pursue a career in research, UCSF has a great atmosphere of collegiality. It's fantastic to be surrounded by experts in the fields who are willing to share, help and collaborate.
cons: Postdoc renumeration is barely adequate especially for an institution located in one of the most expensive cities to live in in the United States and the world.

review_title: Not taking care of its people
job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in San Francisco, CA
pros: UC postdoc union is working to protect people's right and it is big enough to negotiate some good terms, e.g. parental leave
cons: OK working environment, limited and weak career support and career development. UCSF is not taking care of its people. Pay is not good, but the pay for my position is controlled by NIH as well, no supplemental compensation and it costs a lot to work there. and considering it as a state run non-profit organization, its Housing service seems to be making money, instead of providing support. Rent is high as compared to stipend / wages.

review_title: UCSF is a good for entry-level science graduates and for more experienced RA's with family, but there are caveats.
job_title: Staff Research Associate II in San Francisco, CA
pros:
UCSF is a very stable place to work. My work environment wasn't stressful nor did I have pile ons of work. However, I worked in the laboratory and my duties were very clear cut. 

The benifets package given by UCSF is amazing for a family, however, as a single and healthy person I would much rather have been able to trade some of the benefits for increased pay.

Since I worked in a small laboratory I was also able to stand out and be recognized for my work. For this work I recieved a promotion well ahead of the curve. However, I would have to say it was a lucky anomaly of hard work, and a position opening up.  

I would have to say that I'm glad I started at UCSF despite my short period of time there. I gained alot of experience because the academic nature of my lab meant that I had some latitude in how I did things. I wasn't simply turning a crank like a position in Industry might be.
cons:
The pay was atrocious compared to industry. I worked in the laboratory and the equivalent position in industry would have been 25 to 30% better paid at a minimum. also, with the current economic recession and the states' shortfalls I would expect that the pay gap has grown even greater. 

Also, promotions and advancement is generally pretty slow.

review_title: Work/life balance is not just talk here
job_title: Programmer/Analyst IV in San Francisco, CA
pros: Having a family - this is one of the best places to work. They really value employees and have a lot of perks to show that. I like that my schedule is flexible and supported.
cons: Some of the paperwork can be overwhelming. However, things have gotten a lot better and the system seems to be running a little faster and smoother in the last year. The pay and pay freezes may not be the best but the other perks make up for it.

review_title: UCSF labs and its spirit of collaboration make it a worthwhile place to do research, despite administrative red tape.
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in San Francisco, CA
pros: UCSF is a small institution, so it's easy to meet and collaborate with researchers in other labs. The lab culture is relaxed but the science is top-notch.
cons: There are no clear time-off policies for graduate student researchers. The maternity/paternity leave is only 6 weeks, which seems to short. The administration is very baroque and bureaucratic, and can be a constant source of frustration.

review_title: Life at the bottom of the barrel
job_title: Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: Wonderful benefits.  Some very wonderful people.
cons:
The campus is falling apart and being put back together by noisy construction crews during business hours.  Imagine being on a phone call and having a jackhammer drilling into the wall next to your desk.  This is not an exaggeration.  They really do that.

Imagine having so little workspace that the back of your chair is always bumping up against someone else's chair.  Imagine you can smell your co-workers because they're crammed in so closely.  Imagine being closely observed all the time by a half-dozen others.   We're like chickens in an egg factory, and the lights are always on to make us produce more, faster, more, faster.

Analysts and admins often work just as many hours as scientists and physicians - without bonuses, raises, comp time or even a thank you.  They will never get a big prize for solving some brilliant medical question, but they are pressured to work just as hard and fast as those they serve.   They are often reminded in small ways that their educations are not as expensive, prestigious or extensive as those they serve.  If you work here long enough, you will be referred to as a "lifer."  This is their term for "loser."  

We have sexism, racism, elitism, and every other ism, all practiced openly against those who lack the MD or PhD degree.  Go ahead and call the whistleblower hotline.  Nothing will happen.

Our salaries are public information.  Anyone can find out what you earn.  This leads to great bitterness and lack of cooperation among those of identical rank who are compensated differently.

Job protection is a wonderful thing, but it should be possible to fire someone who is not doing a good job (or isn't doing anything at all).  It should be possible to fire someone whose behavior includes screaming, vicious gossip, throwing things.  Worse.  Here, they just get promoted.

Oh, and there's no free parking.

job_title: Staff Research Associate in San Francisco, CA
pros: Good learning environment to kick-start your career.  Be sure to find a good mentor to follow and try to learn as much as you can.  There is wiggle room to take on different task due to the academia environment.
cons: Little to no room for growth.  Senior management does not care or see the hierarchy of new and old employees.  Some employees will just sit there the entire day and do nothing while others are scrambling to finish the work.

job_title: Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros:
UCSF attracts and employs world-class faculty and has some of the world's brightest thinkers in medicine, dentistry and overall research. 

UC still has a pension although it is less robust for new hires. Benefits are still decent but UC decreases its contributions each year.
cons:
Human resources administration is a nightmare. Systems are laughably outdated and processes are still very manual and antiquated. HR analysts no matter what level do the same work. They just support different departments. The work is not truly HR, instead work is funneled through a ticketing system and assigned to generalists. It's glorified admin work.

And sadly, there is a severe lack of forward thinkers in HR, its counterparts in benefits and payroll and other supporting departments. It can be very challenging working with an aging population who think in black and white terms and has the mentality of an admin versus a true analyst who can look at the big picture and come to a logical conclusion versus someone who must be given exact directions in order to perform even the most simple actions. 

Constant reorganization in the name of Operational Excellence  has sent many employees fleeing because there is no transparency or communication around the changes. Moral is extremely poor. Those who are sticking through it fall into two categories; those who are happy doing what they are told because they have been doing it for years or those who would lose too much by leaving with regards to their pension. 

HR  management does not seem to mind that people are leaving in droves. There is an attitude that anyone can be replaced. There are very limited opportunities for advancement. Feedback for process improvement is often request but when it's given, it's ignored.

review_title: Perfect Job for Recent Biology Graduates
job_title: Staff Research Associate in San Francisco, CA
pros: SRA 1 at UCSF is the perfect position for someone who has recently completed a bachelor's in biology. Although the pay is not fantastic and the commute is absolutely horrendous if you live in the east bay, the skills you will develop while working in the lab for the first time as a professional will be worth it for future career endeavors and possibly graduate school.
cons: There is not much commuting support for east bay residents despite so many employees coming from Berkeley and Oakland.

review_title: Typical Incompetent Public Sector Work Environment
job_title: Analyst III in San Francisco, CA
pros: Agree like other posts that they have good benefits. Working on Parnassus campus has the best infrastructure.
cons: In terms of administration (not research), mid-managers beware because the admins and senior managers are incompetent. However, this all depends on the department you. Some departments are better than others but overall it seems the bad depts outnumber the good. The bright admins or senior managers that exist soon leave for more money and better work environments. This then leaves behind the "lifers" and staff with limited skills to work with.  If you start there thinking you can change it, there will be disappointment.

job_title: Program Director in San Francisco, CA
pros:
- mission driven 
- working with the field's best and brightest 
- innovative 
- benefits 
  - pension vested after 5 years 
  - opt into numerous options for tax free sheltered investments 
  - health plan w/ dental 
- easy to transfer to different groups
cons:
- a lot of red tape/regulations/bureaucracy 
- huge -> easy to get lost or lose track 
- runs at the speed of academics with state governance as a spare leg 
- dynamics all dependent on the group/division/supervisor 
- compensation
- work ridiculous hours with this group

job_title: Personnel ANalyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: The best reson to work at UCSF is because it is an environment that inspires growth. The mission, to improve health worldwide through education, and with ground breaking research, makes this company THE place to work.
cons: People, but people are everywhere.

job_title: Preceptorship Coordinator in San Francisco, CA
pros: U.C.S.F. was a wonderful place to work that gave me the opportunity to develop an polish my management skills.   U.C.S.F.  encourages personal and carrier development.   While every department is different, for the most part it is a place where people want to come to work.
cons: Advancement can be slow, this is of course the part of the State of California. However U.C.S.F. is a place where you can work on your goals, whether they are internal or external to the university.

review_title: Overall positive experience with some down sides
job_title: Senior Program Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great people, strong institutional values, good community, good work life balance, flexible work schedules, decent benefits, interesting projects, sense of pride working for an institution that has contributed to positive change around the world
cons: Funding insecurity for research centers that operate without core funding, always in fundraising mode, university bureaucracy that makes the simplest tasks difficult to get through red tape, open office space layout, mission bay location makes it difficult to commute from most locations in the bay area, lots of construction, opening of Chase Center makes commute more difficult for UCSF employees

review_title: Know what you are getting into.
job_title: Staff Research Associate II in San Francisco, CA
pros: The research opportunities and resources are endless. Some of the greatest scientist conduct research here. UCSF is such a prestigious campus that any P.I that works is worth working for.
cons: Job satisfaction depends on the lab you are working for. Some labs hardly publish and some do frequently. If you are in the job for a publication then just be aware.

review_title: Learned a lot, and have great memories, but many things could have been much smoother with the appropriate support
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in San Francisco, CA
pros: There is a tremendous amount of talent at this institution, as well as a diverse array of resources.
cons: UCSF is a public institution, and appears to always be riding the ragged edge financially.  One consequence of this is considerable consolidation/turnover of the administrative staff in recent years, which can make it really hard to get things done effectively.  Also, student health benefits are quite paltry.

review_title: Great training with exposure to top-notch research.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Exposed to may exciting research opportunities. Had the chance to work with some of the brightest. Lab budgets vary, but overall the institution is capable of drawing public grants and funds.
cons: Red tape, lots of policies to slow things down, pay is not that great.

review_title: it really depends on the lab you're in
job_title: Staff Research Associate I in San Francisco, CA
pros: UCSF is a good start if you plan on applying to graduate school such as medical, pharmacy, ph.d,...etc. In academia research, you get to learn a lot on a variety of skills and techniques, however, every lab is different. Some labs are crazy and can be hostile at times. There are some people at other labs that have nicer Principal Investigators with better management and cared for their co-workers! Just choose wisely.
cons:
-long hours and terrible work life balance
-lab politics
-taking advantage of free labors from volunteers/intern students
-some managers/supervisors just doesn't have management skills

review_title: Where good careers admin careers go to die
job_title: Administrative Analyst IV in San Francisco, CA
pros: Comfortably numb. You'll hardly know that you're working most of the time, unless you're one of the unlucky ones that picks up all of the slack for the coworkers that refuse to do any work. You can literally do nothing all day long (again, unless you somehow get stuck in the role of "Office Scapegoat - Every UC Office has one. You might end up being that One.) Lots of autonomy because most of your bosses have NO idea what your work entails or how you do your job. You get to feel like the smartest person in the room when you realize that most of your coworkers haven't updated their skills in 15-20 years. Sidewalk Art Events and other such nonesense consantly, unless you're unlucky enough to work at the SFGH Campus, then none of those events are for you.
cons: Zero communication between departments, management, and coworkers about the work, or what's going on in the department. And endless mysterious barrage of Initials (most people at UC mistakenly call them "acronyms", but aren't smart enough to realize what an "acronym actually is) for various divisions that are constantly changing and nobody tells you. People just expect you to know, then laugh and mock you when they mention the initials in a meeting and you have no idea what they are talking about. Bureacracy and red tape enough to kill your soul and make you realize why most government is ineffective. You know those non-profits that people complain about that waste a lot of their money on administrative costs and don't end up using the money on actual resources for those in need? You get to see that up close and personal. Lots of government waste, like throwing away almost new equipment (printers, copiers) to buy All-In-One machines that are inefficient and use up insanely expensive amounts of toner. Insane policies that you have to follow that are decided upon by a committee several pay grades above you, who have no idea what you actually do, and who will never have any idea how their ineffective policies have destroyed your job and made it extremely difficult to perform. Directories in buildings that have been replaced with the names of donors and VPs instead, because that's somehow more important to UC than showing people how to get from point A to point B. The list of insanity is endless.

review_title: The most important mission in the world...advancing health worldwide
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: World-class medical school and research institution, many different disciplines and cultures offer myriad opportunities to do different kinds of work. Changing the way health care is practiced, working to cure disease.
cons: Huge organization: each department is an island and highly matrixed, which can make it a difficult environment to navigate. Important areas of infrastructure (research administration, HR, IT) are not being provided sufficient resources to do an increasing amount of work, leading to frustration of both staff and customers.

job_title: Data Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: good pay & benefits, union protection, spellbinding cocktail party conversation based on daily hair raising insanity, when you leave you have no regrets, the bonding that happens under painful circumstances
cons: working with deeply unhappy, bitter & obstructive people, drama, severe dysfunction, verbal abuse from arrogant doctors, being reposted to another division that doesn't have an office for you for more than a month so you work out of the library,  starting a job with four people in a room without desks or phones for weeks sharing a single laptop,  being directed to violate the law by ignorant & incompetent superiors

review_title: Enlightening and interesting place to work
job_title: Several in San Francisco, CA
pros: I"ve worked in several departments at UCSF.  All in all I was treated well and encouraged by each of the managers for whom I worked.
cons: The "cons" were typical of working as an admin in almost any environment...the inherent conflicts between worker bees and managers..lack of adequate salary increases and the like.

review_title: Used to be great, still trying desperately to hang onto that, faculty not really doing their jobs
job_title: "Postdoc" in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Lots of people will be impressed that you work here, because of the past glory, multiple Nobel Prizes, and the healthcare coming out of the hospital. They have good facilities if you can get access to them through the bureaucracy. 

You will meet some excellent co-workers who are also trapped in an essentially broken system and bond over shared pain.
cons:
Faculty have no job responsibilities, if they decide to start a company and stop showing up, the school won't stop them. 

Training is non-existent. You will do all the work, you will get none of the credit.

Cronyism & nepotism everywhere when hiring new people.

Racism, sexism, general harassment of anyone different is rampant and nobody wants to talk about it. You can sexually harass and bully your co-workers for years and nothing will happen to you.

Average faculty member is over 55 years old, white, male and a jerk.

Faculty are only managed by other faculty. See problems with faculty. 

Grad students do almost everything but get none of the credit. Grad students & postdocs expected to work all the time with no time off. Faculty don't have time off because they don't really show up in the first place.

The compensation is awful for being the most expensive city in the USA. You will not get paid what you are worth unless you are one of the rich old white male faculty members. No cost-of-living adjustments for grad students or postdocs. You'd make the same at a school in Oklahoma.

The school really did have a great history, many people are trying to hold onto that, but it is getting out of hand very quickly. Faculty often leave for greener pastures, which would be great if they were replaced with new, young, energetic faculty. But they are replaced with old cronies.

Most faculty do a very poor job of helping you get a job once you are done. Expect to get by purely on the UCSF name.

job_title: Director in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great benefits, flexible schedule including telecommute options. Lots of opportunities to continue training and personal development, if you can find a way to carve out time to take advantage of these offerings.
cons: Tends to have unclear promotion structure for administrative roles, and somewhat flat salaries. Currently understaffed in many areas, which has had an impact on overall moral.

job_title: Postdoctoral Scholar in San Francisco, CA
pros: UCSF is a leader not only in basic science and translational research, but also in the innovation of career development strategies.  The career services office offers robust services for all postdocs and graduate students to pursue both academic and non-academic career paths, and the location of UCSF in the Bay Area makes it an ideal location to obtain top-notch postdoctoral experience while networking in industry at the same time.
cons: The salary and benefits are the lowest that can be legally given to a postdoc.

job_title: in San Francisco, CA
pros: UCSF is the abbreviation for Univerity of California San Francisco but employees of UCSF says it means U Can Stay Forever. Employees have found long term work and job opportunities here.
cons: The University doesn't pay into state disability, they offer their own disability insurance, if you're still an employee when you need it. If you become disabled and are no longer an employee, you have no disability payment benefits options from the state.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Working for one of the Bay Area's largest employers looks pretty good on a resume. Organized and comprehensive onboarding process.
cons: Employees are expected to work when they are sick or injured which, from a public health perspective, is not a smart (unwritten) policy for a hospital system.  Bureaucracy and internal politics are pervasive. Unqualified people are promoted or stay in positions for many, many years flying under the radar.

job_title: PhD Graduate Student in San Francisco, CA
pros: Excellent collaborative environment and access to cutting-edge technologies. Many of the PI's are leading experts and pioneers in their respective fields. The office of career development provides excellent career resources and organizes extremely useful career development and networking programs. The Mission Bay campus is new, and very nice. Added perk of being in the vibrant city of San Francisco.
cons: Unfortunately I've encountered administrative hurdles due to the bureaucratic nature of UCSF from time to time. Also it's difficult to make ends meat on the stipend given the high cost of living in the bay area.

review_title: Registered Nurse - ICU full time staff
job_title: Registered Nurse in San Francisco, CA
pros: Best management I have every worked for. Reimbursement deal for getting your master's at UCSF  is pretty great, and my coworkers rock!
cons: Like any place, you got so bigger egos (surgeons), some unexperienced NP/PA but all  in all, it is a wonderful teaching hospital, and our fellows and attendings are awesome to work with

review_title: UCSF is great if you don't have kids and work for a good PI
job_title: Sra III in San Francisco, CA
pros: UCSF has an excellent reputation and some of the premier researchers in the world. I respect the PI I work for and have wonderful freedom to pursue independent projects using cutting edge resources.
cons: The pay scale is not equivalent to the biotech fields. More than once has a Post-Doc gotten more credit for equivalent  work.

job_title: Assistant Clinical Research Coordinator in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great team at UCSF Memory and Aging Center. Dr. Bruce Miller is a wonderful leader. Physicians, nurses, social workers, and psychologists really care about the research and are great to work with.
cons: A lot of turnover with coordinators, because we all go off to graduate schools. This can make getting big projects done a struggle. The data technology is also pretty outdated with bad UX.

job_title: Postdoctoral Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: 1. World-class research. 2. Access to the best infrastructure one can possibly get in a university or even an industry setting. 3. Best place to network with academic and industry leaders. 4. Good union that looks after the well-being of post-doctoral scholars and reseachers.
cons: Visa restrictions for international students causes minor difficulties when starting a new post doc. However, the same is true at any other university. So, this is not really a deal-breaker when you look at the pros of being at UCSF.

review_title: I worked at UCSF for 35 years. No large organization can be perfect, but UCSF strives to achieve meaningful progress.
job_title: Research Specialist in San Francisco, CA
pros: Truly inspired people to work with. Good facilities. Many opportunities for lower level (non-PhD) researchers.
cons: Research has become extremely competitive accompanied by the stress of constant innovation. If you like it then it is a great environment. You have to find the right people to work with.

job_title: Analyst IV in San Francisco, CA
pros: Provides a variety of positions and opportunities for people who want a change or who want to move up and even for those who want stability and consistency.
cons: The last few years, the benefits and retirement package has been on a steady downgrade.  Advancing in your current job/department can be slow.  People who are willing to move within the University will probably find themselves advancing faster than those who stay in one department.

job_title: in San Francisco, CA
pros: The Benefits are good for the old timers. They are tolerant of mistakes.
cons:
They have recently changes the benefits any new employee will get mediocre benefits. 
Major moral problem. In 2011 they did a Gallup Survey and were ranked very low on Employee Engagement. The CA budget has played havoc on UCSF priorities and  middle management is so over worked they have no time to give simply complements. Employees must submit their achievements to receive recognition.

job_title: Program Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: Many opportunities for growth and learning.  Good benefits plus random discounts on things like City Car Share, Sports Basement, and others.  The shuttle system is also very useful and helps with getting around to the various offices/campuses spread around the city.
cons: Typical bureaucratic issues associated with working for a large, public organization.  Explicit funding rules make it difficult for managers to use their own discretion with spending, including salary negotiations.  Takes a longtime ice for paperwork to go through.

job_title: Staff Research Associate II in San Francisco, CA
pros: Proactive organization. Lots interesting and cutting-edge research going on. Facilities are generally nice and up-to-date.
cons: Salaries for non-faculty staff members are very low relative to the cost of living in San Francisco and most of the rest of the Bay Area. Benefits are not great, including health insurance, which is ironic for a medical school. Many research and technical positions are union positions, requiring a monthly contribution, but I'm not convinced union representation has improved anything for members, especially considering the laughably low wages for the Bay Area.

review_title: It was a great learning experience.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great benefits, an atmosphere of collegiality, great locations and campuses. UCSF is a world class employer. Diverse and engaged workforce
cons: Intellectual snobbery, Ivory Tower mentality and all it's attendant sins. Still guilty of pimping out the poor and disadvantaged communities. Not willing to engage institutional self criticism and systemwide reform.

job_title: Resident Physician in San Francisco, CA
pros: The location is obviously unbeatable.  The facilities are also well maintained.  The patients and the overall culture of medicine in the region are both very good.
cons:
Like many public institutions, UCSF suffers from inefficiencies.  

This may or may not be a "con" depending on your perspective, but unions seem to be quite strong in the region.

job_title: in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Benefit package used to be one of the best, but with the economic crunch, employees are losing more of their benefits (having to pay more in premiums and reduction in retirement funding)

Biggest pro is to work with leading researchers and medical professionals in the country
cons:
Salary is not commensurate with the (immense) amount of work employees have to do

There is a hierarchy in terms of recognition/respect

job_title: Administrative Assistant III in San Francisco, CA
pros: Professional development opportunities are encouraged, good salary, collaboration among different levels at the hospital, the feeling that you are making a difference
cons: I was there during Operational Excellence and I wasn't effected but many of my co-workers were upset by the changes that caused.

job_title: Postdoctoral Scholar in San Francisco, CA
pros: UCSF is a top-notch medical university with access to unlimited resources for procuring grant funding and conducing research. UCSF provides numerous training and career planning activities for postdoctoral fellows.
cons: UCSF has a highly competitive and siloed work environment. It is not always conducive to collaboration. Many high-profile researchers have little time to mentor students. Great work environment for highly motivated and self-directed postdocs.

job_title: Sra III in San Francisco, CA
pros: Opportunity to work with multiple departments and cutting edge technology, with field leaders and experts. Opportunity for growth as long as you seek it! Leaders in science and medicine but
cons:
Everyone except (science related positions) seems happy with their pay?
I always feel like I'm missing a few zero's at the end!

job_title: Research Associate in San Francisco, CA
pros: I worked with amazing and extremely intelligent people, so the standards were set relatively high from the beginning. This allowed me to grow and progress intellectually. My duties and responsibilities were diverse and challenging enough for me not to get bored.
cons: Due to the busy nature of my PI and my postdoctoral mentor, sometimes it was a bit confusing and difficult to carry out appropriate planning of experiments. This lead to wasting of materials and time.

review_title: Cutting-edge science and good funding if you know where to look
job_title: PhD Student in San Francisco, CA
pros: Good connections with Bay Area biotech and pharma. Top scientists, decent funding (very dependent on lab). Newer facilities and equipment.
cons: Lots of buzz words and hype (so far) surrounding newer initiatives. Some of these are not very friendly to student involvement, unlike other universities.

job_title: Research Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: Always a lot of activity with cutting edge research, opportunities to understand the operations of a public academic institution, generally beautiful campus
cons: Little room for growth for anyone who is not a MD or PhD, so expect to be treated as a second- or third-class citizen if your title is not "Doctor"

job_title: Patient Care Technician in San Francisco, CA
pros: None, none, none. Work here if you are young,  white and not from the Bay Area. Another words you must be racist and have very little experience with diversity.
cons:
Abusive work environment. 

Their chief nursing officer is a racist pig, who keeps a list of names of people to not hire. Sadly, most of them are Asian.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in San Francisco, CA
pros: It is a beautiful campus to work in, and you receive great experience interacting with the patients in a clinical setting.
cons: Highly underpaid for the amount of work that is assigned. There is no clear communication between upper management and HR.

job_title: Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: Benefits & perks (if you can afford them), pension plan (if hired before 2013). Better to come in by way of organization's internal temporary employment program to see which divisions actually has funding.
cons: Non-competitive salary (3% merit increments annually); who you know, not what you know; lack of growth within team/departments - need to search externally to advance.

review_title: Amazing to be a part of this academic community
job_title: Staff Research Associate III in San Francisco, CA
pros: Collaboration is wonderful here with lots of opportunities to work with a varied group of people. People work here because they love the science. One of the best scientific environments I have ever been involved with.
cons: The unions make is very difficult to get any kind of pay increases. If you work hard it is for yourself and not to make more money. Otherwise, some people are lazy and don't have to worry about being fired.

job_title: in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great location, staff friendly, my particular area was undergoing several issues that were unpleasant, culminating with a change in Associate Director; great staff medical benefits, low compays and low out of pocket
cons: So many issues from State Budget cuts, help to employees facing unfair treat the not forthcoming and dependent on whoever answers you in HR.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in San Francisco, CA
pros: Name recognition for people interested in applying to medical or graduate school. Opportunities to go to academic lectures. You will be surrounded by smart and altruistic people.
cons: Non-competitive salaries, no perks, no room for growth or development. Stifled by unions. Mission Bay campus doesn't have any good lunch options nearby.

job_title: Programmer/Analyst II in San Francisco, CA
pros: Very comfortable place to work, mostly everyone is very accomadating and welcoming. Perks like holidays, work schedule, telecommuting are really great. Work-life balance is very important in some departments.
cons: The University as a whole is a bit disjointed, both physically and as a company. Its also a public institution, so things are not as competitive as private companies. Some departments are very family-oriented, so you don't see many of the typical "San Francisco" job perks like free laptops, outrageous holiday parties, free lunches.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: It is top notch research university with good resources and very smart people. It has a very nurturing environment. It provides very good heath insurances and generous vacation/sick days. overall very good benefits.
cons: The compensation is on the low end, especially with regard to the living expenses in the bay area. you might be able to manage if you are single.

review_title: well, it's the only real academic research institute in the city of SF
job_title: Staff Research Associate II in San Francisco, CA
pros: world class research institute and one of the world's most prestigious medical centers.
cons: California budget crunch leads to less than competitive salaries.  Career staff are low on the "totem pole" compared with academics.

review_title: A great place to do biomedical research, but not without its challenges.
job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in San Francisco, CA
pros: UCSF is a great academic environment to do science. The atmosphere is highly collaborative. The strong biomedical emphasis and ties with biotech industry help make basic science research more relevant and translational.
cons: UCSF suffers many of the same issues as other members of the UC system - the institution is highly bureaucratic and administrative processes are frustratingly inefficient/slow. Minimum pay for postdocs follows NIH guidelines, which makes survival in San Francisco a challenge.

job_title: Staff Research Associate II in San Francisco, CA
pros: Friendly and hardworking people, flexible work environment (in my lab). I appreciated being able to share my honest opinions and suggestions. Vendor shows and health fairs were fun and a good way to bring UCSF together. Good benefits.
cons: Research salary was not that great so turnover rate for research associates can be high, depending on the lab. Not that many part time opportunities, some lab managements don't like it. Parking is hard (but that can be said for all of SF).

review_title: Great place for postdocs to grow into professional scientists.
job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in San Francisco, CA
pros: A lot of career development and exploration opportunities for post-docs. Great benefits thanks to the UC postdoc union. Facilities for research are outstanding. There are a lot of shared core facilities in the various campuses with outstanding equipment to facilitate cutting edge research. Collaborations with hospitals and other partners allow us to translate our research a lot easier.
cons: Cost of living in San Francisco, transportation, having to move from campus to campus for seminars, etc.

job_title: Pediatric Resident in San Francisco, CA
pros: UCSF provides fantastic clinical exposure; senior residents feel comfortable in a wide range of environment and are prepared to address difficult cases. The quality of the residents in this program is consistently very high.
cons: This is definitely NOT a "cush" program. There is a lot of work, especially when on certain services. While the workload is stressful, it prepares well-prepared residents.

review_title: Amazing place to work! Staff extremely helpful and friendly
job_title: Patient Care Attendant in San Francisco, CA
pros: Learning facility support nurse assistant who return to school for RN. The RNs do not dump on their assistants and are just as involved. Excellent benefits package.
cons: I started of here as a temp through registry and didn't get facility specific training which I think would've been helpful so maybe a short orientation for registry staff wanting to become permanent would be good.

review_title: Teams are very efficient in working with staff and patients.
job_title: Outpatient Clinic Coordinator in San Francisco, CA
pros: Patient care is high on the list. Team members work together to get projects done. Supervisors work with staff to reach care goals.
cons: Company is restructuring and expanding, causing a little confusion at times. Things sometimes change without notifying all the affected participants. The changes are showing how different departments interact, which is sometimes unexpected.

review_title: I worked as a graduate student researcher
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Good learning environment.
San Francisco is a amazing (albeit expensive) city to live in.
Very good opportunities to get mentored in innovation and other similar fields.
The facilities at the Mission Bay campus are really nice.
cons:
Getting a PhD takes a long time and is incredibly stressful.
The facilities are old (at Parnassus).
It's very difficult to afford to live here because of the high cost of living.
It's very difficult to get research funding in general, so make sure you work in a well-funded lab.

job_title: Assist Director Internet Services in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great work environment. They have a nice balance between work/life where they understand the importance of family. In my position as project manager,working in the Dean's office, I worked on a variety of projects which I really liked. It is great to work with a bunch of smart people.
cons: There are no real downside to working at the School of Medicine. The one thing I noticed was it was hard to get promoted, at least within the Dean's Office.

job_title: Analyst III in San Francisco, CA
pros: The work is very satisfying in terms of doing interesting research that applies directly to patients care and advancement of medical field. Very flexible environment, feel appreciated for the work done. Sufficient benefits (vacation, sick leave, etc)
cons: Very hard to move from staff to academic site, even when credential are sufficient. With furloughs and budget cuts the work load increased tremendously, but the morale is decreasing.

job_title: Programmer/Analyst II in San Francisco, CA
pros: If you are not interested in growth but need a paycheck without putting too much of yourself into it, this might be a good place to work for. The pay and benefits is actually not bad.
cons: Everything is dumbed down. Inovation is discouraged, professional growth is zero and people are generally fairly incompetent.

review_title: Very blessed to have employment at this highly respected institution
job_title: CSWII in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Good pay
Innovative
Good benefits
Sense of doing good for the community
Passionate staff and managers -- usually
cons:
If you work on the Campus side, as I do, you see the big disparity between Campus & Medical Center
Extremely hierarchical
You have to make your own opportunities for advancement, and yell about your accomplishments from the rooftops! Otherwise, senior managers may not notice.

job_title: IT Field Services Technician in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great organizational mission. Great customers. Good technology. Good team environment. Set hours. Job duties are well described and accurate. Many points of contact if help is needed.
cons: Limited chance for upward mobility. Management is disorganized and lacks enterprise-wide experience. Tons of dead weight sitting around waiting for pensions to kick in. Good place to park your career if this is your last stop.

job_title: Specialist in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great research team and super talented people around the world get together to help people! Relaxing environment and less pressure like industry! Close to golden gate park (Parnassus campus) ! If you would like to stay in academic position forever it's great university and environment! if you are looking for money it's not place you're looking for and you're in wrong place!
cons: There is no much space for growing! Take too much time to get promoted!

review_title: My 14 years experience at UCSF has been very positive and rewarding.
job_title: Staff Research Associate II in San Francisco, CA
pros: UCSF offers many excellent benefits packages to its employees. I have worked at several jobs within UCSF system and never had a bad supervisor. The research facilities are state of the art and with the new Mission Bay campus, crowding at the Parnassus campus has been relieved.
cons: Some UCSF departments are scattered at various sites ALL OVER the city which can create problems in connecting with other people.

job_title: Assistant Clinical Research Coordinator in San Francisco, CA
pros:
+ Cutting-edge research
+ Good benefits 
+ Flexible schedule
+ Awesome shuttle system
+ Super helpful IT team
cons:
- Overworked and underpaid; expect to work extra hours without compensation and very little appreciation
- Lack of support and training/mentoring
- Unclear expectations and guidance on how to improve
- Unclear rules and procedures for tedious administrative tasks

review_title: Much work, little money, little appreciation
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Scientist in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great to network in the UCSF community. Great to learn new technical skills. Great to have a career office.
cons: Postdocs receive less wages than technicians. Their assignments are sometimes technician level, and not much possibility to (first author) publication.  Overseas postdocs on visas have not much choice but go back to home country if their situation is not as great as they expected it.

review_title: Great intellectual environment immersed in a dynamic city.
job_title: in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great intellectual environment immersed in a dynamic city. Lots of places to go after work. MUNI transportation exists, but service is mediocre. BART and Caltrain tranportation exists.
cons: The campus is divided into multiple mini-campuses around the city. Although, an employee mostly stays within area so travelling is not a major concern. Housing in SF is expensive.

review_title: People at UCSF work there for the prestige of being connected with a research institution
job_title: in San Francisco, CA
pros: Nice place to work, nice people. Really caring about wellness of everyone, as any healthcare organization would.  Great reputation as a world class healthcare organization, Nice brand new buildings.
cons: Pay not too good.  Salaries and benefits are at the mercy of the state budget.  There is a class system, with doctors being on top, and everyone else is a peon.

review_title: Good place to be a graduate student, but much better at the Mission Bay Campus
job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in San Francisco, CA
pros: The benefits are quite good for students.  The Mission Bay campus has much better facilities than Parnassus.
cons: Graduate students work hard.  It's quite difficult to find a job after your PhD other than a post-doc.  It would be better if students were required to complete multiple rotations in multiple labs, even if it meant that they might take longer to graduate.

job_title: in San Francisco, CA
pros: You have flexibility to arrange your experiment and plan. The professor is very accessible. There are a lot of opportunities to learn new technologies.
cons: When the funding climate is tight like today, a lot of labs are losing funding, and lab size is cutting down. Some of good scientists are losing their confidence.

review_title: Tough to get around the city at times between the various campuses.  Great benefits and better pay.
job_title: Chief Administrative Officer in San Francisco, CA
pros: Benefits, smart people, great mission.  UCSF Health has grown into a powerhouse and continues to do so with innovative partnerships and service.
cons: Commute to SF and around SF.   Often need to do multi-campus work; however, the tech is somewhat lacking and is often disjointed.

job_title: Researcher in San Francisco, CA
pros: Smart people work hear and they are very nice and friendly! you have flexible hours! if you close to parnassus campus you are very close golden gate park and it's 5 mins walk from campus and you can go for walking during lunch hours! If you're looking for growing in your career in research area this is place you're  looking for!
cons: Salary is not very high! This is university and you should expect that!

review_title: Highly decentralized environment without a true recruiting team.
job_title: Human Resources Professional in San Francisco, CA
pros: Excellent employee benefits.  Both the research and school are world-class.
cons: If in middle management or below major salary disparity between employees and management.  Additionally, no training development opportunities or succession planning.  Employees have to take the initiative, but many just get stuck doing the same positions for many years.  As a result of the salary disparity, UCSF is unable to attract the A players so innovation is lacking.

job_title: Programmer/Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: If you are looking for a flexible and stable non-faculty or research career, UCSF is the place to be!
cons: This varies by unit or departments you working, Because of the sheer size of UCSF, there isn't one common culture at UCSF, so each individual employee experience may vary.  As with any non-profit/government job, the pay is less compared to the private-sector.

review_title: I had a great experience working there
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: It was a great opportunity to work with and learn from people that were experts in their field.  The work was meaningful and I learned a lot from the position.  The environment was very accomodating, allowing for flexible hours, telecommuting, and the position did not require overtime.
cons: Of course the salary at a university is not going to be close to what the salary would be in industry.

review_title: UCSF is a good stepping stone to new places
job_title: Associate Specialist in San Francisco, CA
pros: Lots of vacation and useful experience. My manager was great with lots of new ways to learn. I was able to choose most of my hours but ended spending most of my time in the lab
cons: Low pay unless you have a very large pedigree and lots of letters after your name. Unless you have a MD or PhD you hit a ceiling very quickly.

job_title: Field Service Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: Amazing mission, working with talented and driven team members. Can truly say you leave the world a better place everyday.
cons: Anything and everything can be politicized. It takes a while to navigate the bureaucratic nodes, can fill overwhelming at times.

job_title: Postdoctoral in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Lots of great scientists
Lots of great resources
Near Gladstone Institute
Very new facilities
Near public transit
On campus apartments
cons:
Local neighborhood dangerous - lots of assaults and robberies occur every year
Expensive and the surrounding area also expensive
Takes a lot of time to get to main campus (Parnassus)

review_title: Good opportunities if you have a good supervisor or manager
job_title: Analyst V in San Francisco, CA
pros: UCSF has some great managers who really care about their employees, and some that are not well trained at all.  Since it's such a large organization, you really have to drive your own career.
cons: There are so many systems, not all updated.  Getting things done is some times difficult, especially if something is an exception.

job_title: Project Analyst II in San Francisco, CA
pros:
*University environment 
*Great retirement benefits
*Career growth opportunity
cons: Department of Surgery HR does not help you when dealing with unacceptable behavior from management which is why I ended up leaving. The work environment was very hostile for everyone in my division working under a specific administrative director and manager.  I felt there was no way out when HR wasn't able to help me.

job_title: Analyst II Supervisor in San Francisco, CA
pros: UCSF has great medical, dental and vision benefits, and while the pay looks good to start, there is really no pay increases unless you get promoted. Since the average tenure at the university is very high (over a decade), that means few opportunities for advancement.
cons: Poor advancement opportunities. No bonuses for positive performance

review_title: learned about life in a big research institution
job_title: Postdoctoral Scholar in San Francisco, CA
pros: talented people, well-resourced, great seminars, innovative research and researchers
cons: focus is on only biomedicine and not the social context of health. UCSF has little commitment to its junior people, so you must bring in your entire salary if you want to stay

review_title: Hard work, looks good on CV, low compensation
job_title: Associate Specialist in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Great institute with excellent infrastructure that has the possibility to give you lots of valuable experience.
Large community with great opportunity to meet peers. Lots of collaboration between groups and Pis
Flexible hours, if you want to.
Good benefits (vacation, sick days, health insurance etc.)
cons: Long hours, with low compensation in relation to what is expected of you. Very hard to make a living in San Francisco with this salary level.

review_title: Brilliant people to work with, still in the public sector so working with tough budgets.
job_title: Resident Physician in San Francisco, CA
pros: Brilliant colleagues.  Won't find people around that are smarter.  Academic setting that gives great exposure.  I would make the choice again.
cons: Depends on what department you are in.  I work in a very incestuous department that just hires each other and swaps around positions, so at times it feels stagnant.

job_title: Administrative Assistant III in San Francisco, CA
pros: Good pay for steady work. There are many small perks and groups that you can participate in at any level of service.
cons: It's hard to work with Doctors. It is hard to advance past the AA or Analyst postions. Career advancement is concentrated to Managers, Directors, and upper management. Very little career advancement for support staff.

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in San Francisco, CA
pros: equal opportunity, active research environment, excellent alumni resources, tons of collaboration opportunity, bay area location, mature tech transfer mechanism, smart and diligent ppl to work with
cons: locate in san francisco so the living cost is pretty high. biomedical focused university, so culture wise is not diversified. postdoc activity/community is kind of weak.

review_title: Administrative Supervisor manages a campus and clinical unit.
job_title: Administrative Supervisor in San Francisco, CA
pros: Mission and goals of institution is a Nobel one, helping advance research, support education, pioneer in research and clinical care.
cons: Leaders don’t have time or take time to recognize or appreciate staff and or compensate as equally compared to other positions performing same functions.

job_title: Analyst II in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great benefits.  Great library.  Good access to lunch choices.
cons: Managers and faculty can be dishonest in presenting opportunities for advancement.  No real mechanism for providing positive feedback to individual employees.  Late or no performance reviews.  Very little training.

review_title: It is a great opportunity for learning.
job_title: in San Francisco, CA
pros: Working with some of the best Scientists and doctors is a great experience.
cons:
1) It can be hectic if you work in labs as your hours will be defined by the need of experiment and
2)  most PI will not automatically give you a promotion unless you ask for one.

job_title: Graduate Student in San Francisco, CA
pros: The new Mission Bay campus is gorgeous. Top notch research facility. Access to many resources, the hospitals, and talents from a variety of fields.
cons: Work culture depends on the lab you are in so it varies a lot. Long work hours but it can be very flexible. Overall no complaints.

review_title: Collaborative, supportive environment of highly intelligent and motivated peopple
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in San Francisco, CA
pros: The faculty is really top notch, and highly supportive and collaborative, treats students and staff research associates well and provides them with many opportunities for growth and development.
cons: High amount of red tape, little communication between administrative departments, hospital, and research labs, constant new and unclear rules/processes for administrative procedures. Not competitive salary and benefits package.

job_title: Administrative in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great research institution, incredible minds on the academic side.
cons: Outside of the professors, postdocs, and students, it is rare to find people other than the "No" bureaucrat model. One has to pull teeth to get anything done, especially if a task requires multiple departments (e.g., HR and Payroll) to work together. It's maddening.

review_title: Great opportunities for advancement if you are proactive, but don't expect any hand holding pr support from HR.
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in San Francisco, CA

cons: HR is pretty incomeptent, SLOW, and disorganized.  If you want to get moved up within your grade or steps, have to work a lot with your supervisor to make it happen.

review_title: practice manger at UCSF HAVE TOO MUCH POWER
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: none i can think of
cons: the practice mangers think they are Nurses, just glorified secretary with big ego, totally unprofessional, they treat staff terrible

review_title: Its a great place to learn and do research.
job_title: Postdoctoral Scholar in San Francisco, CA

job_title: Analyst I in San Francisco, CA

cons: Stiff hierarchy.  If you accept a job as Analyst 1 it will be an arduous road to making it to the next level.  UCSF really needs Analyst 1 people, and it can take many many years before you can move ahead.  Advice: avoid the Analyst 1 title, when accepting a job.

review_title: UCSF is terrible working environment unless you are a manager
job_title: Analyst II in San Francisco, CA
pros: - UCSF is a well known school
cons:
- Upper management could care less about staff
- Terrible human resource staff

job_title: Staff Research Associate II in San Francisco, CA

Surrounded by really good researchers. There are a lot of great speakers and interesting talks.
Good benefits and free shuttles to various UCSF locations.
cons:
Depending on the department you work in, HR service is not really helpful when you are in need.
As a research associate in a very small lab, it was difficult to have a promotion or a raise but you can get a lot of responsabilities.

job_title: Assistant Researcher in San Francisco, CA

job_title: Postdoctoral Scholar in San Francisco, CA

job_title: Clinical Applications Lead in San Francisco, CA

-Strongest in research and innovation
-Still has a pension program
-Respect for unions
-Attracts quality
cons:
-Hard to remove poor performers (U Can Stay Forever)
-Salaries can't keep up with Bay Area costs
-Decisions have to be obtained via consensus/slow
-Parking anywhere is nuts

job_title: in San Francisco, CA
pros:
It's in San Francisco
Great gym facilities
Handy shuttling to local transit stations
State of the art facilities
Close to a lot of things
cons:
A very eyes down environment, people aren't exactly keen on really getting to know one another
It's very easy to get absorbed into the cubicles

job_title: IT Leader in San Francisco, CA

review_title: I commute from the Sacramento area but despite this UCSF is a great place to work.

job_title: Staff Research Associate II in San Francisco, CA

review_title: A place of welcoming and smart people

Worldwide competitive salaries
Work with world-class experts and leaders
Great work ethic
Welcoming with all cultures

cons: There were none... Actually, I felt a fish-out-of-water when i got there, but quickly I learned to raise my abilities and standards in science and research!

job_title: in San Francisco, CA

review_title: Not payed enough for the San Francisco standard. A lot of very smart people. High turnover. Slow pace.

You’ll learn a lot.
People are nice. A lot of very smart people. Slow pace. Overall good place. I enjoyed working here.
cons:
No maternity leave.
Not payed enough for the San Francisco standard. High turnover. Slow pace. The salary increases only 2% yearly (if you ask for it)

amazing career office

review_title: Amazing, innovating and forward thinking place to work and grow.

review_title: Fine Institution, but tight with pay in an expensive city

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA

review_title: Challenging but Fulfilling place to work.
job_title: Associate Professor, Residence in San Francisco, CA
pros: Top notch colleagues, important mission, exciting time to work in medicine and biomedicine. Academic environment supports creativity.
cons: Fiscal challenges UC is facing can lead to uncertainty or lack of resources to carry out mission. Pay for clinical work is lower than at other health care systems(Kaiser).

job_title: Postdoctoral Fellow in San Francisco, CA
pros: Good research environment, great faculty, nice place to be. Good research equipment
cons: Lots of disconnect between different departments, sometimes hard to find the correct person to do the job you need done.

job_title: Postdoctoral Scholar in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great academics, well-structured departments, good resources, and one of the best career development center for postdocs
cons: Fellows with MD get preferential treatment in research labs,  in some departments senior investigators dominate, as in most institutions, poor oversight of postdoc rights
